{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Other uses|Evacuation Day (disambiguation){{!}}Evacuation Day}} {{Infobox holiday | holiday_name = Evacuation Day | type = historical | image = Evacuation Day and Washington's Triumphal Entry.jpg | imagesize = 350px | caption = ''Evacuation Day and Washington's Triumphal Entry'' | official_name = | nickname = | observedby = [[New York City]] | litcolor = | longtype = | significance = Date when the last British troops left New York | begins = | ends = | date = November 25 | firsttime = {{Start date|1783|11|25}} | duration = 1 day | frequency = annual | scheduling = varies | celebrations = | observances = | relatedto = }}
'''Evacuation Day''' on November 25 marks the day in 1783 when British troops departed from [[History of New York City|New York City]] on [[Manhattan|Manhattan Island]], after the end of the [[American Revolutionary War]]. After this [[British Army]] evacuation, General [[George Washington]] triumphantly led the [[Continental Army]] from his former headquarters, north of the city, across the [[Harlem River]], south down [[Manhattan]], through the town to [[Battery Park|The Battery]] at the foot of Broadway.<ref>{{cite book|title=A Toast To Freedom: New York Celebrates Evacuation Day|year=1984|publisher=Fraunces Tavern Museum|page=7}}</ref>
The last shot of the war was reportedly fired on this day, as a British gunner fired a cannon at jeering crowds gathered on the shore of [[Staten Island]], as his ship passed through [[the Narrows]] at the mouth of [[New York Harbor]]. The shot fell well short of the shore.<ref>[http://www.nypl.org/branch/staten/index2.cfm?Trg=1&d1=962&template=timeline3 Staten Island on the Web: History<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Background== [[File:Prison Ship Martyrs' Monument and flags.jpg|thumb|alt=The column of the Prison Ship Martyrs' Monument, topped by a bronze urn, among trees, with a modern American and POW/MIA flagstaff adjoining.|[[Prison Ship Martyrs' Monument]], [[Wallabout Bay]], [[East River (New York)|East River]], (now [[Fort Greene Park]]), [[History of New York City|New York]]-[[History of Brooklyn|Brooklyn]]]]
Following the devastating losses at the [[Battle of Long Island]] on August 27, 1776, General [[George Washington]] and the [[Continental Army]] retreated across the [[East River (New York)|East River]] by benefit of both a retreat and holding action by well-trained [[Maryland Line]] troops at [[Gowanus Canal|Gowanus Creek and Canal]] and a night fog which obscured the barges and boats evacuating troops to Manhattan Island.<ref>Field, Thomas Warren. ''The Battle of Long Island: With Connected Preceeding Events, and the Subsequent American Retreat'' Long Island Historical Society, 1869, page 250</ref> On September 15, 1776, the British flag replaced the American atop Fort George, where it was to remain until Evacuation Day.
Washington's Continentals subsequently withdrew north and west out of the town and following the [[Battle of Harlem Heights]] and later action at the river forts of [[Battle of Fort Washington|Fort Washington]] and [[Battle of Fort Lee|Fort Lee]] on the northwest corner of the island along the [[Hudson River]] on November 16, 1776, evacuated [[Manhattan Island]]. They headed north for [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]], fought a delaying action at [[Battle of White Plains|White Plains]], and retreated across New Jersey in the [[New York and New Jersey campaign]].
For the remainder of the [[American Revolutionary War]], much of what is now [[City of Greater New York|Greater New York]] was under [[Kingdom of Great Britain|British control]]. [[History of New York City (1665–1783)|New York City]] (occupying then only the southern tip of Manhattan, up to what is today Chambers Street), became, under [[Richard Howe, 1st Earl Howe|Admiral of the Fleet Richard Howe, Lord Howe]] and his brother [[William Howe, 5th Viscount Howe|Sir William Howe, General of the British Army]], the British political and military center of operations in [[British America|British North America]]. [[David Mathews]] was [[Mayors of New York City|Mayor of New York]] during the British occupation. Many of the civilians who continued to reside in town were [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Loyalists]].<ref>Calhoon, Robert M. "Loyalism and neutrality" Chapter 29, p. 235. Greene, Jack P. and Pole, J.R. ''A Companion of the American Revolution'' (2004)</ref>
On September 21, 1776, the city suffered a [[Great Fire of New York (1776)|devastating fire]] of uncertain origin after the evacuation of Washington's [[Continental Army]] at the beginning of the British Army occupation. With hundreds of houses destroyed, many residents had to live in makeshift housing built from old ships.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Homberger |first1=Eric|title=The Historical Atlas of New York City, Second Edition: A Visual Celebration of 400 Years of New York City's History|date=2005|publisher=Macmillan |isbn=978-0-8050-7842-8|page=56|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8EgsHmSEAsC&pg=PA56}}</ref> In addition, over 10,000 Patriot soldiers and sailors died through deliberate neglect on [[Prisoners in the American Revolutionary War|prison ships]] in New York waters ([[Wallabout Bay]]) during the British occupation—more Patriots died on these ships than died in every single battle of the war, combined.<ref>{{cite book |last=Stiles |first=Henry Reed |author-link=Henry Reed Stiles|title=Letters from the Prisons and Prison-ships of the Revolution |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B20FAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover |publisher=Thomson Gale (reprint) |date=1865 |isbn=978-1-4328-1222-5}}</ref><ref>Dring, Thomas and Greene, Albert. "Recollections of the Jersey Prison Ship" (American Experience Series, No 8). Applewood Books. November 1, 1986. {{ISBN|978-0-918222-92-3}}</ref><ref>Taylor, George. "Martyrs To The Revolution In The British Prison-Ships In The Wallabout Bay." (originally printed 1855) Kessinger Publishing, LLC. October 2, 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-548-59217-5}}.</ref><ref>Banks, James Lenox. "Prison ships in the Revolution: New facts in regard to their management." 1903.</ref><ref>Hawkins, Christopher. "The life and adventures of Christopher Hawkins, a prisoner on board the 'Old Jersey' prison ship during the War of the Revolution." Holland Club. 1858.</ref><ref>Andros, Thomas. "The old Jersey captive: Or, A narrative of the captivity of Thomas Andros...on board the old Jersey prison ship at New York, 1781. In a series of letters to a friend." W. Peirce. 1833.</ref><ref>Lang, Patrick J.. "The horrors of the English prison ships, 1776 to 1783, and the barbarous treatment of the American patriots imprisoned on them." Society of the Friendly Sons of Saint Patrick, 1939.</ref><ref>Onderdonk. Henry. "Revolutionary Incidents of Suffolk and Kings Counties; With an Account of the Battle of Long Island and the British Prisons and Prison-Ships at New York." Associated Faculty Press, Inc. June 1970. {{ISBN|978-0-8046-8075-2}}.</ref><ref>West, Charles E.. "Horrors of the prison ships: Dr. West's description of the wallabout floating dungeons, how captive patriots fared." Eagle Book Printing Department, 1895.</ref> These men are memorialized, and many of their remains are interred, at the [[Prison Ship Martyrs' Monument]] in [[Fort Greene Park]], [[Brooklyn]].
==Event history==
===British evacuation from New York=== In mid-August 1783, [[Sir Guy Carleton]], then the last [[British Army]] and [[Royal Navy]] commander in the former [[British America|British North America]], received orders from his superiors in London for the evacuation of New York. He informed the President of the [[Confederation Congress]] that he was proceeding with the subsequent withdrawal of refugees, liberated slaves, and military personnel as fast as possible, but that it was not possible to give an exact date because the number of refugees entering the city recently had increased dramatically (more than 29,000 [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Loyalist]] refugees eventually were evacuated from the city).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uelac.org/Loyalist-Ships/Loyalist-Ships.php|title=UELAC.org - Loyalist Ships|website=www.uelac.org|language=en|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref><ref> Grasso, Dr. Joan S. ''The American Revolution on Long Island'' Arcadia Publishing, 2016, page 110 </ref> The British also evacuated over 3,000 [[Black Loyalist]]s, former slaves they had liberated from the Americans, to [[Nova Scotia]], East [[Florida]], the [[Caribbean]], and [[London]],<ref> Lanning, Michael Lee. ''African Americans in the Revolutionary War'' page 161.</ref> and refused to return them to their American slaveholders and overseers as the provisions of the [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|Treaty of Paris]] had required them to do. The [[Black Loyalist#Black Brigade|Black Brigade]] were among the very last to depart.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cCMbE4KKlX4C&pg=PA139|title=Encyclopedia of African American History, 1619-1895: From the Colonial Period to the Age of Frederick Douglass Three-volume Set|last=Finkelman|first=Paul|date=April 6, 2006|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=9780195167771|language=en}}</ref>
Carleton gave a final evacuation date of 12:00 noon on November 25, 1783. An anecdote by [[Alexander Anderson (illustrator)|Alexander Anderson]] told of a scuffle between a British officer and the proprietress of a boarding house, as she defiantly raised her own American flag before noon.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CmMSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA235|title=Hours with the Living Men and Women of the Revolution: A Pilgrimage|last=Lossing|first=Benson John|date=1889|publisher=Funk & Wagnalls|language=en}}</ref> Following the departure of the British, the city was secured by American troops under the command of General [[Henry Knox]].<ref name=Margino>[http://www.nypl.org/blog/2014/11/24/evacuation-day-new-york-holiday Margino, Megan. "Evacuation Day: New York's Former November Holiday", New York Public Library, November 24, 2014]</ref>
Entry into the city under General [[George Washington]] was delayed until after a British flag which could be seen still flying had been removed: a British [[Union Flag]] had been nailed to a flagpole at [[Fort Amsterdam|Fort George]] on [[The Battery (Manhattan)|the Battery]] at the southern tip of Manhattan as a final act of defiance, and the [[Greasy pole|pole was greased]]. After a number of men attempted to tear down the British colors, wooden cleats were cut and nailed to the pole and, with the help of a ladder, an army veteran, John Van Arsdale, was able to ascend the pole, remove the flag, and replace it with the [[Flag of the United States|Stars and Stripes]] before the British fleet had completely sailed out of sight.{{sfnp|Riker|1883|loc=[https://books.google.com/books?id=8BQvAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA16 pp. 16–18]}}<ref name = "Hood 2004 6">Hood, C. 2004, p. 6. [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2005/is_4_37/ai_n6137401 Clifton Hood] in his essay on New York's Evacuation Day makes the following citation for John Van Arsdale's role in removing the Union Flag and replacing it with the Stars and Stripes: ''Rivington’s New York Gazette'', November 26, 1783; ''The Independent New-York Gazette'', November 29, 1783; Edwin G. Burrows and Mike Wallace, ''Gotham: A History of New York to 1898'' (New York, 1999): 259–61; Douglas Southall Freeman, ''George Washington: A Biography, v. 5, Victory with the Help of France'' (New York, 1952): 461; James Thomas Flexner, ''George Washington, v. 3, In the American Revolution (1775–1783)'' (Boston, 1967): 522–8. Van Arsdale has sometimes been identified as an Army enlisted man or an Army officer. The flag later joined the historic collection at [[Scudder's American Museum]] but unfortunately was destroyed in a fire in 1865.</ref> That same day, a [[liberty pole]] with a flag was erected at [[New Utrecht Reformed Church]]; its successor still stands there.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newutrechtchurch.org/history.htm|title=Church History|website=www.newutrechtchurch.org|access-date=August 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=joI8DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA726|title=AIA Guide to New York City|last=White|first=Norval|last2=Willensky|first2=Elliot|last3=Leadon|first3=Fran|last4=Chapter|first4=American Institute of Architects New York|date=June 9, 2010|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|year=|isbn=9780195383867|location=|pages=276|language=en}}</ref> Another liberty pole was raised in [[Jamaica, Queens]], in a celebration that December.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b6hhDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT38|title=George Washington’s 1790 Grand Tour of Long Island|last=Grasso|first=Dr Joanne S.|date=July 9, 2018|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|year=|isbn=9781439664766|location=|pages=38|language=en}}</ref>
===Washington's entry into New York=== Seven years after the retreat from [[Manhattan]] on November 16, 1776, General [[George Washington]] and Governor of New York [[George Clinton (vice president)|George Clinton]] reclaimed [[Fort Washington (Manhattan)|Fort Washington]] on the northwest corner of [[Manhattan Island]] and then led the [[Continental Army]] in a triumphal precision march down the road through the center of the island onto [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] in the Town to [[Battery Park|the Battery]].<ref> Baker, William S. Itinerary of General Washington from June 15, 1775, to December 23, 1783 (concluded)''The Pennsylvania Magazine of History and Biography '' Vol. 15, No. 4 (1891), pages 419–420. </ref> During his stay, Washington had a meeting with [[Hercules Mulligan]], which helped dispel suspicions about the tailor and spy.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tcFLAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA124|title=The Original American Spies: Seven Covert Agents of the Revolutionary War|last=Misencik|first=Paul R.|date=December 10, 2013|publisher=McFarland|year=|isbn=9780786477944|location=|pages=124|language=en}}</ref>
===Gallery=== <gallery heights="200px" widths="200px" mode="nolines"> File:Bennett Park New York Manhattan Fort Washington Memorial Mark.jpg|Monument in [[Bennett Park (New York City)|Bennett Park]] marking the November 16, 1776, evacuation and the November 25, 1783 triumphal entry of the American forces File:Washington's entry into New York 1783, Currier and Ives 1857.jpg|''Washington's Entry into New York'' by [[Currier & Ives]] File:Washington's grand entry into New York, Nov. 25th, 1783.jpeg|''Washington's Grand Entry into New York, November 25, 1783'' by Alphonse Bigot File:George Washington by John Trumbull 1790.jpg|alt= American General George Washington stands in front of a white horse, with Bowling Green and the Battery in the background, on Evacuation Day, November 25, 1783|''[[George Washington (Trumbull, 1790, New York City Hall)|George Washington, Evacuation of New York]]'', by [[John Trumbull]], 1790, [[New York City Hall]] File:Henry Kirke Brown George Washington statue by David Shankbone.jpg|[[Henry Kirke Brown]]'s ''[[George Washington (Brown)|George Washington]]'' in [[Union Square, Manhattan|Union Square]] commemorates Washington's entrance to the city on Evacuation Day </gallery>
===Aftermath=== A week later, on December 4, at [[Fraunces Tavern]], at Pearl and Broad Streets, General Washington formally said farewell to his officers with a short statement, taking each one of his officers and official family by the hand.<ref>{{cite web|title=Today in History – December 4: Goodbye to General Washington|url=https://www.loc.gov/item/today-in-history/december-04#goodbye-to-general-washington|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]}}</ref>
Later, Washington headed south, being cheered and fêted on his way at many stops in [[New Jersey]] and [[Pennsylvania]]. By December 23, he arrived in [[Annapolis, Maryland]], where the [[Confederation Congress]] was then meeting at the [[Maryland State House]] to consider the terms of the Treaty of Paris. At their session in the Old Senate Chamber, he made a short statement and offered his sword and the papers of his commission to the President and the delegates, thereby [[George Washington's resignation as commander-in-chief|resigning as commander-in-chief]]. He then retired to his plantation home, [[Mount Vernon]], in [[Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Today in History – December 23: Washington Resigns His Commission|url=https://www.loc.gov/item/today-in-history/december-23#home-for-the-holidays|publisher=Library of Congress}}</ref>
==Commemoration==
===Early popularity=== [[File:View of Battery Park 1793.jpg|thumb|View of the commemorative flagpole at the Battery in its "gigantic [[Butter churn|churn]]", during a visit by the French frigate [[French frigate Embuscade (1789)|''Embuscade'']] (shortly before the [[Action of 31 July 1793]])]]
Public celebrations were first held on the fourth anniversary in 1787, with the city's garrison performing a [[Military parade|dress review]] and [[feu de joie]], and in the context of a Federalist push for constitutional ratification following the [[Constitutional Convention (United States)|Philadelphia Convention]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nysarchivestrust.org/magazine/archivesmag_fall2010|title=Fall 2010, Volume 10, Number 2 {{!}} New York State Archives Partnership Trust|website=www.nysarchivestrust.org|language=en|access-date=February 4, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0z--xlX9rlYC&pg=PA180|title=My American Revolution: A Modern Expedition Through History's Forgotten Battlegrounds|last=Sullivan|first=Robert|date=September 4, 2012|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=9780374217457|language=en}}</ref>
The British [[Fort Amsterdam|Fort George]] at Bowling Green was demolished in 1790, and in that year the Battery Flagstaff was built on newly reclaimed land on the Battery, called the "churn", operated by William and then Lois Keefe; this was replaced in 1809, and demolished about 1825. In 1809, the new flagstaff further east on the Battery with a decorative [[gazebo]], which was operated as a concession.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mQnTQjSS5qEC&pg=PA9|title=Writing New York: A Literary Anthology|last=Lopate|first=Phillip|date=2000|publisher=Simon and Schuster|year=|isbn=9780671042356|location=|pages=9|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FQ9IAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA98-IA14|title=Pictures of Early New York on Dark Blue Staffordshire Pottery: Together with Pictures of Boston and New England, Philadelphia, the South and West|last=Halsey|first=Richard Townley Haines|date=1899|publisher=Dodd, Mead|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nycgovparks.org/about/history/timeline/oldest-parks|title=The Oldest Parks : Online Historic Tour : NYC Parks|website=www.nycgovparks.org|access-date=November 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AwoIAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA402|title=The iconography of Manhattan Island|last=Stokes|first=I. N. Phelps|date=|publisher=Robert H. Dodd|year=1915|isbn=9785871799505|location=|pages=402|language=en|quote=|author-link=Isaac Newton Phelps Stokes|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fn8_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA236&lpg=PA236|title=A History of the People of the United States|last=McMaster|first=John Bach|date=|publisher=D. Appleton|year=1915|isbn=|volume=Volume II 1790–1803|location=|pages=|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> The Battery Flagstaff commemorated Evacuation Day, and was the site of the city's annual flag-raising celebration with a 50 x 100 foot flag for over a century. A flag-raising was held twice a year, on Evacuation Day and on the [[Independence Day (United States)|Fourth of July,]] and after 1853 flag-raisings on these days were also held at [[Blockhouse No. 1 (Central Park)|The Blockhouse]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HsVXAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA3520|title=The City Record|last=|first=|date=1895|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=3520|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kmoSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA95|title=Roster of the Veteran Corps of Artillery Constituting the Military Society of the War of 1812|last=1812|first=Military Society of the War of|date=1901|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":3" />
On Evacuation Day 1790, the [[Veteran Corps of Artillery of the State of New York]] was founded.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5QBGAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA290|title=Proceedings of the Board of Aldermen|last=Aldermen|first=New York (N Y. ) Board of|date=1895|publisher=The Board|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=290|language=en}}</ref>
John Van Arsdale is said to have been a regular flag-raiser at the early commemorations.<ref name=":3" />
[[Washington Irving]] described a September 1804 visit to the commemorative flagpole, as "The standard of our city, reserved, like a choice handkerchief, for days of gala, hung motionless on the flag-staff, which forms the handle to a gigantic [[Butter churn|churn]]," in his ''A History of New York''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PrFEAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA183|title=A History of New-York, from the Beginning of the World to the End of the Dutch Dynasty: In Two Volumes|last=Irving|first=Washington|date=January 1, 1830|publisher=Carey & Lea|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=183|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref>
The [[Scudder's American Museum]] / [[Barnum's American Museum]] held what it claimed was the original 1783 Evacuation Day flag until the museum's burning in 1865, and flew it on Evacuation Day and the Fourth of July.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=R3MUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA285&lpg=PA285&dq=1783+#v=onepage&q=1783&f=false History of the Flag of the United States of America], p. 285-86 (1880)(reporting that the flag was destroyed in the 1865 fire of Barnum's)</ref>
On Evacuation Day 1811, the newly completed [[Castle Clinton]] was dedicated with the firing of its first gun salute.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=so4-clY2m70C|title=Castle Clinton|last=Service|first=United States National Park|date=1976|publisher=U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service|language=en}}</ref>
On Evacuation Day 1830 (or rather, on November 26 due to inclement weather), thirty thousand New Yorkers gathered on a march to [[Washington Square Park]] in celebration of that year's [[July Revolution]] in France.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=thWVcHVixF4C&pg=PA71|title=It Happened on Washington Square|last=Folpe|first=Emily Kies|date=|publisher=JHU Press|year=2002|isbn=9780801870880|location=|pages=71–72|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vp1YAAAAcAAJ|title=Oration delivered in commemoration of the Revolution in France|last=Gouverneur|first=Samuel L.|date=|publisher=|year=1830|isbn=|location=|pages=|language=en|quote=|author-link=Samuel L. Gouverneur|via=}}</ref>
For over a century the event was commemorated annually with patriotic and political connotations, as well as embracing a general holiday atmosphere.<ref name=":0" /> Sometimes featured were [[greasy pole]] climbing contests for boys to recreate the taking the down the Union Jack.<ref name=":2" /> Evacuation Day also became a time for theatrical spectacle, with for example an 1832 [[Bowery Theatre]] double bill of [[Junius Brutus Booth]] and.[[Thomas D. Rice]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xPmrVehxWwAC&pg=PA121|title=Junius Brutus Booth: Theatrical Prometheus|last=Archer|first=Stephen M.|date=August 20, 2010|publisher=SIU Press|isbn=9780809385928|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yxupgt6nNFMC&pg=PA21|title=Burnt Cork: Traditions and Legacies of Blackface Minstrelsy|last=Johnson|first=Stephen|date=2012|publisher=Univ of Massachusetts Press|isbn=1558499342|language=en}}</ref> David Van Arsdale is said to have raised the flag after his father's death in 1836.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" /> There was also a traditional parade from near the current [[Cooper Union]] down [[Bowery|the Bowery]] to the Battery.<ref name=":3" />
<gallery> File:Flagstaff and Churn at the Battery.jpg|Painting of flagstaff and "churn" at the Battery File:Grand Canal Celebration- View of the Fleet Preparing to Form in Line MET 49G 111R6.jpg|The "churn" after its retirement as flagstaff, ca. 1825 File:The Traveler's First View of New York—The Battery and Flagstaff MET DP153927.jpg|A view of the second Battery Flagstaff about 1812, with surrounding [[gazebo]] </gallery>
===Mid-19th century and decline=== [[File:Evacuation Day Parade of First Division, New York State Militia, newspaper illustration MET MIDP2005.126.2.jpg|thumb|left|Evacuation Day Parade of First Division under [[Charles W. Sandford]], New York State Militia, 1866]] [[File:Booths Caesar.jpg|thumb|upright|''Julius Caesar'' at The Winter Garden Theatre, with [[John Wilkes Booth]], [[Edwin Booth]], and [[Junius Brutus Booth, Jr.]], November 25, 1864.]] The importance of the commemoration was waning in 1844, with the approach of the [[Mexican–American War]] of 1846–1848.<ref name=nyt1924>{{cite news|title=Evacuation Day was once a glorious holiday here|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1924/10/19/archives/evacuation-day-was-once-a-glorious-holiday-here-dinner-of-sons-of.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 19, 1924}}</ref>
However, the dedication of the monument to [[William J. Worth]], the Mexican–American War general, at [[Madison Square]] was purposely held on Evacuation Day 1857.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iplIKaa54eoC&pg=PA32|title=Out of Fire and Valor: The War Memorials of New York City from the Revolution to 9–11|last=Snyder|first=Cal |date=January 1, 2005|publisher=Bunker Hill Publishing, Inc.|year=|isbn=978-1-59373-051-2|location=|pages=32|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref>
In August 1863, the Battery Flagstaff was destroyed by a lightning strike; it was subsequently replaced.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1863/08/07/news/the-storm-yesterday.html|title=The Storm Yesterday.|date=August 7, 1863|work=The New York Times|access-date=January 13, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1863/08/20/news/general-city-news.html|title=General City News.|date=August 20, 1863|work=The New York Times|access-date=January 13, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
Before it was a national holiday, Thanksgiving was proclaimed at various dates by state governors – as early as 1847, New York held Thanksgiving on the same date as Evacuation Day, a convergence happily noted by [[Walt Whitman]], writing in the ''[[Brooklyn Eagle]]''. The observance of the date was also diminished by the [[Thanksgiving Day (United States)|Thanksgiving Day Proclamation]] by 16th President [[Abraham Lincoln]] on October 3, 1863, that called on Americans "in every part of the United States, and also those who are at sea and those who are sojourning in foreign lands, to set apart and observe the last Thursday of November next as a day of thanksgiving."<ref name="lincoln">{{Cite web |last=Lincoln|first=Abraham|authorlink=Abraham Lincoln|url=http://showcase.netins.net/web/creative/lincoln/speeches/thanks.htm|title=Proclamation of Thanksgiving|date=October 3, 1863|publisher=Abraham Lincoln Online|accessdate=September 11, 2011}}</ref> That year, Thursday fell on November 26. In later years, [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] was celebrated on or near the 25th, making Evacuation Day redundant.<ref name="rodwan">{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanhumanist.org/HNN/details/2010-11-no-thanks|first=John G.|last=Rodwan, Jr.|title=No Thanks|work=Humanist Network News|date=November 20, 2010|accessdate=September 11, 2011|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807050729/http://www.americanhumanist.org/HNN/details/2010-11-no-thanks|archivedate=August 7, 2011}}</ref>
On Evacuation Day 1864, the Booth brothers held a performance of ''Julius Caesar'' at the [[Winter Garden Theatre (1850)|Winter Garden Theatre]] to raise funds for the [[William Shakespeare (Ward)|Shakespeare statue]] later placed in Central Park. That same day, [[Confederate Army of Manhattan|Confederate saboteurs]] attempted to burn down the city, lighting an adjoining building on fire, and for a time disturbing the performance.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=Sam|author-link=Sam Roberts (newspaper journalist)|title=As Booth Brothers Held Forth, 1864 Confederate Plot Against New York Fizzled|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/25/nyregion/as-booth-brothers-held-forth-1864-confederate-plot-against-new-york-fizzled.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b3-zWPYjcGoC&pg=PA106|title=The Man Who Tried to Burn New York|last=Brandt|first=Nat|date=July 1999|publisher=iUniverse|year=|isbn=978-1-58348-346-6|location=|pages=106|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-melting-pots-melting-point-1471030618|title=A Melting Pot’s Melting Point|last=Holzer|first=Harold|date=August 12, 2016|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=August 6, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_3nADAAAQBAJ&pg=PA781|title=The Oxford Handbook of Shakespearean Tragedy|last=Neill|first=Michael|last2=Schalkwyk|first2=David|date=August 18, 2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780191036149|language=en}}</ref>
A traditional children's rhyme of the era was:<blockquote>''It's Evacuation Day, when the British ran away,<br>Please, dear Master, give us holiday!{{sfnp|Riker|1883|loc=[https://books.google.com/books?id=8BQvAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA22 p. 22]}}</blockquote>
Over time, the celebration and its anti-British sentiments became associated with the [[Irish Americans in New York City|local Irish American community.]]<ref name=":0" />
===Centennial and 20th century fading=== [[File:Evacuation of New York by the British crop.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Raising the [[Flag of the United States|Stars and Stripes]], 1883 print showing a variant of the [[Cowpens flag]] and a completely inauthentic [[Union Jack]] ]] [[File:The Old Guard of New York raising the flag on Evacuation Day.jpeg|thumb|The [[Old Guard (New York)|Old Guard]] of New York raising the flag on Evacuation Day at the Battery, 1897.]] In the 1890s, the anniversary was celebrated in [[New York City|New York]] at [[Battery Park]] with the raising of the [[Flag of the United States|Stars and Stripes]] by Christopher R. Forbes, the great grandson of John Van Arsdale, with the assistance of a Civil War veterans' association from Manhattan—the [[Anderson Zouaves]].<ref>''"The Sunday Advocate (Newark, Ohio)"'' November 26, 1893, {{quote |NEW YORK, Nov As the sun rise guns pealed forth at Fort William. [[Old Glory]] was run up to the truce of the city flagstaff at [[Battery Park]] on the site where stood the staff to which the British nailed their flag before sailing down the harbor. The British flag was torn down and replaced by the American colors by Van Arsdale, the sailor boy, and the "flag run up by one of his lineal descendants, Christopher R. Forbes, who was assisted by officers of the [[Anderson Zouaves]]. The flag was saluted by the guns at [[Fort Amsterdam|Fort William]].}} ''New York Times'', November 26, 1896, {{quote |The day was also celebrated by raising the flag at sunrise at the Battery by Christopher R. Forbes, great-grandson of John Van Arsdale, assisted by the Anderson Zouaves. Sixty-second Regiment, New-York Volunteers. Capt. Charles E. Morse, and Anderson and Williams Post, No. 394, [[Grand Army of the Republic]].}}</ref> [[John Lafayette Riker]], the original commander of the Anderson Zouaves, was also a grandson of John Van Arsdale. Riker's older brother was the New York genealogist [[James Riker]], who authored ''Evacuation Day, 1783''{{sfnp|Riker|1883|loc=[https://books.google.com/books?id=8BQvAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA3 p. 3]}} for the spectacular 100th anniversary celebrations of 1883, which were ranked as “one of the great civic events of the nineteenth century in New York City.”<ref>Goler, 'Evacuation Day', ''The Encyclopedia of New York City'', p. 385.</ref> David Van Arsdale had died in November 1883 just before the centennial,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1883/11/15/archives/an-old-veteran-gone-death-of-david-van-arsdale-at-the-age-of-87.html|title=AN OLD VETERAN GONE.; DEATH OF DAVID VAN ARSDALE AT THE AGE OF 87 YEARS.|access-date=August 12, 2018|language=en}}</ref> having helped revive the event the year previous,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_8ugAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA38|title=Annual Record|last=Massachusetts|first=Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of|date=1883|publisher=A. Mudge and son, printers.|language=en}}</ref> and he was succeeded by his grandson.<ref name=":3" />
As part of Evacuation Day celebrations in 1883 (on November 26), the ''[[George Washington (Ward)|George Washington]]'' statue by Federal Hall was unveiled.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8jr6vNLLYMgC&pg=PA148|title=American Sculpture in the Metropolitan Museum of Art: A catalogue of works by artists born before 1865|last=N.Y.)|first=Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York|last2=Dimmick|first2=Lauretta|last3=Hassler|first3=Donna J.|date=1999|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|year=|isbn=9780870999147|location=|pages=148|language=en}}</ref>
On Evacuation Day 1893, the ''[[Nathan Hale (statue)|Nathan Hale]]'' statue currently in City Hall Park was unveiled.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8jr6vNLLYMgC&pg=PA434|title=American Sculpture in the Metropolitan Museum of Art: A catalogue of works by artists born before 1865|last=N.Y.)|first=Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York|last2=Dimmick|first2=Lauretta|last3=Hassler|first3=Donna J.|date=1999|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|year=|isbn=9780870999147|location=|pages=434|language=en}}</ref>
In 1895, [[Asa Bird Gardiner]] disputed the rights to organize the flag-raising, claiming that his organization, the [[General Society of the War of 1812]], were the true heirs of the [[Veteran Corps of Artillery of the State of New York|Veteran Corps of Artillery]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HPgQAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA83|title=The Spirit of '76|date=January 1, 1895|publisher=Spirit of '76 Publishing Company|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cItGAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA472|title=Proceedings of the Board of Aldermen|last=Aldermen|first=New York (N Y. ) Board of|date=1896|publisher=The Board|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=472|language=en}}</ref>
In 1900, Christopher R. Forbes was denied the honor of raising the flag at the Battery on [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] and on Evacuation Day<ref>''New York Times'', July 3, 1900, {{quote |<p>Christopher R. Forbes, who for many years has had the privilege of raising and lowering the flag at the Battery on Evacuation Day and the Fourth of July, and claims that he inherited the right from his great-grandfather, John Van Arsdale, who tore down the British’colors on the spot and hoisted the American flag instead, he feels very sore over the way in which he has been treated by the Park Department. Van Arsdale family members from New York to San Francisco remain aghast. He said last evening:</p> <p>''“Early in June I made an application for permission to raise the flag on the Fourth, and I received a reply from President Clausen, on June 5 giving me permission to participate in the raising of the flag by the employes of the Park Department. Now any tramp can participate in the raising of the flag if he stands by and looks on, and that was the kind of permission that was given to me. If this was not a snub and an insult, I’d like to know what is. When my great-grandfather hauled down the British flag and hoisted the American colors I’d like to know where Mr. Clausen’s great-grandfather was and what he was doing.''</p> <p>''Later even this tramp permission was revoked. To-day I received another letter from Mr. Clausen informing, me that instead of my participating with the Park Department employees in hoisting the flag, that ceremony would be performed by the [[Veteran Corps of Artillery of the State of New York|Veteran Corps of Artillery]], [[Veteran Corps of Artillery of the State of New York|Military Society of the War of 1812]].''</p> <p>''“I saw the hand of [[Asa Bird Gardiner]] behind all this. He tried to do me out of I my privileges before, and he has succeeded now. The Veteran Corps was really wiped out in 1872 and in 1892 Mr. Gardiner was instrumental in organizing the present one. He wanted me and C. B. Riker to join, but we refused.''</p> <p>''In former years the Anderson Post, the Anderson Zouaves, the Anderson Girls, and the Camp Sons of Veterans used to go with me and assist me in the ceremony of raising the flag and now even the tramp permission of participating with employees has been revoked.''</p> <p>''I am going to consult with Mr. Riker about this matter and I shall probably be somewhere near the flag raising Wednesday morning. I think they will hear from me before then.”''</p>}}</ref> and it appears that neither he nor any Veterans' organization associated with the Van Arsdale-Riker family or the Anderson Zouaves took part in the ceremony after this time. In 1901, Forbes raised the flag at the dedication of [[Bennett Park (New York City)|Bennett Park]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I6c_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA232|title=The Church Eclectic|date=1904|language=en}}</ref> Following the warming of relations with Britain immediately preceding [[World War I]], the observance all but disappeared.
In the early 20th century, the flagpole used was that from the 1901 [[America's Cup]] defender ''Constitution''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bklyn.newspapers.com/image/54486373/|title=19 Jun 1910, Page 6 - The Brooklyn Daily Eagle at Newspapers.com|work=Brooklyn Public Library|access-date=August 6, 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lMEMAAAAYAAJ|title=New York: The Metropolis of the Western World ...|last=|first=|date=1924|publisher=Foster & Reynolds|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=22|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zcs3AQAAIAAJ|title=Rider's New York city: a guide book for travelers, with 13 maps and 20 plans|last=Rider|first=Fremont|date=1924|publisher=H. Holt|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=151|language=en}}</ref> The commemorative flagpole was still listed as an attraction in a [[Federal Writers' Project]] city guide as late as 1939,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KEwe-UMAYWEC&pg=PA63|title=New York City Guide (American Guide Series)|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Random House|year=1939|isbn=9781623760557|editor-last=Federal Writers' Project|editor-link=Federal Writers' Project|location=|pages=63|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> and the annual flag-raising ceremony lasted until the 1950s.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0z--xlX9rlYC&pg=PA180&lpg=PA180|title=My American Revolution: A Modern Expedition Through History's Forgotten Battlegrounds|last=Sullivan|first=Robert|date=September 4, 2012|publisher=Macmillan|year=|isbn=9780374217457|location=|page=|pages=179–180|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref>
The event was officially celebrated for the last time on November 25, 1916 with a march down Broadway for a flag raising ceremony by sixty members of the [[Old Guard (New York)|Old Guard]].<ref name="nyt012916">{{Cite news|title=New York Council Resists Renaming Effort to Honor Evacuation Day|last=Roberts|first=Sam|author-link=Sam Roberts (newspaper journalist)|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 29, 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/30/nyregion/new-york-council-resists-renaming-effort-to-honor-evacuation-day.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/arts/an-old-holiday-reborn.html|title=AN OLD HOLIDAY REBORN|last=Goldman|first=Ari L.|date=November 25, 1983|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=November 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=suQWBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA243|title=Forgotten Patriots: The Untold Story of American Prisoners During the Revolutionary War|last=Burrows|first=Edwin G.|date=November 9, 2010|publisher=Basic Books|year=|isbn=0465020305|location=|pages=243–244|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> The position of the flagstaff at this time was described as near Battery Park's sculptures of [[John Ericsson]] and [[Giovanni da Verrazzano]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-rE-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA149|title=New York of To-day|last=Brown|first=Henry Collins|date=January 1, 1917|publisher=Old Colony Press|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=149|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> The flagpole was included on a map of Battery Park in the WPA [[American Guide Series|''New York City Guide'']] of 1939.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KEwe-UMAYWEC&pg=PA63|title=New York City: Vol 1, New York City Guide|last=on|first=Best Books|date=1939|publisher=Best Books on|year=|isbn=9781623760557|location=|pages=63|language=en}}</ref> It was removed sometime in midcentrury. Later, City Council President [[Paul O'Dwyer]] expressed interest in a restored flagpole for the 1976 [[United States Bicentennial]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1976/02/21/archives/plea-for-a-historic-flagpole.html|title=Plea for a Historic Flagpole|date=February 21, 1976|work=The New York Times|access-date=January 13, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> A bicentennial of Evacuation Day in 1983 featured the labor leader [[Harry Van Arsdale Jr.|Harry Van Arsdale, Jr.]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/24/nyregion/new-york-day-by-day-065885.html|title=NEW YORK DAY BY DAY|last=Carroll|first=Susan Heller Anderson and Maurice|access-date=August 6, 2018|language=en}}</ref> A commemorative plaque marking Evacuation Day was put on a flagpole at [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]] in 1996.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hmdb.org/Marker.asp?Marker=41155|title=In Honor of Evacuation Day Historical Marker|access-date=January 13, 2018}}</ref>
The [[Sons of the Revolution]] fraternal organization continues to hold an annual 'Evacuation Day Dinner' at [[Fraunces Tavern]].
===21st century and renewed efforts=== Though little celebrated in the previous century, the 225th anniversary of Evacuation Day was commemorated on November 25, 2008, with searchlight displays in New Jersey and New York at key high points.<ref>[http://blog.nj.com/njv_mark_diionno/2008/11/giant_light_show_to_illuminate.html NJ.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.revolutionarynj.org/newsEvents/revolutionary-war-beacons.php RevolutionaryNJ.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027122223/http://www.revolutionarynj.org/newsEvents/revolutionary-war-beacons.php |date=October 27, 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.hvpress.net/news/125/ARTICLE/5692/2008-11-11.html HVpress.net] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723151007/http://www.hvpress.net/news/125/ARTICLE/5692/2008-11-11.html |date=July 23, 2011 }}</ref> The searchlights are modern commemorations of the bonfires that served as a beacon signal system at many of these same locations during the revolution. The seven New Jersey Revolutionary War sites are Beacon Hill in [[Summit, New Jersey|Summit]],<ref name="beacon">{{Cite web|url=http://www.beaconhillclub.org/|title=Beacon Hill Club|accessdate=September 11, 2011}}</ref> [[South Mountain Reservation]] in South Orange, [[Fort Nonsense (Morristown, New Jersey)|Fort Nonsense]] in Morristown, [[Washington Rock State Park|Washington Rock]] in Green Brook, the [[Navesink Twin Lights]], [[Battle of Princeton|Princeton]], and [[Ramapo Mountain State Forest]] near Oakland. The five New York locations which contributed to the celebration are; [[Bear Mountain State Park]], [[Storm King State Park]], [[Black Rock Forest|Scenic Hudson's Spy Rock (Snake Hill)]] in New Windsor, [[Washington's Headquarters State Historic Site]] in Newburgh, Scenic Hudson's [[Beacon Mountain|Mount Beacon]].
{{multiple image | direction = vertical | header = November 25, 1783<br>Evacuation Day Plaza | image1 = Bowling Green Plaza, New York City - looking south, 2016.jpg | image2 = Bowling Green Plaza, New York City - 1783 Evacuation Day street sign.jpg }} The renaming of a portion of [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]], a street in [[Lower Manhattan]] to Evacuation Day Plaza was proposed by Arthur R. Piccolo, the chairman of the Bowling Green Association, and James S. Kaplan of the Lower Manhattan Historical Society. The proposal was initially turned down by the [[New York City Council]] in 2016 because the Council's rules for street renaming specify that a renamed street must commemorate a person, an organization, or a cultural work. However, with the support of Councilwoman Margaret Chin, and after supporters of the renaming pointed to streets and plazas named after "Do the Right Thing Way", "Diversity Plaza", "Hip Hop Boulevard", and "[[Ragamuffin parade|Ragamuffin Way]]", the council reversed its decision and approved the renaming of the street on February 5, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Plagianos|first1=Irene|title=Bowling Green To Be Co-Named 'Evacuation Day Plaza'|url=https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20160210/financial-district/bowling-green-be-co-named-evacuation-day-plaza|agency=www.DNAinfo.com|publisher=DNAinfo.com: Breaking News, Local Neighborhood News|date=February 10, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170630180812/https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20160210/financial-district/bowling-green-be-co-named-evacuation-day-plaza|archivedate=June 30, 2017}}</ref><ref name=nyt012916/> {{-}}

'''Explo '72''' was an evangelistic conference sponsored by [[Campus Crusade for Christ]], planned and directed by Paul Eshleman. Explo '72 has been called the most visible event of the 1970s [[Jesus movement]],<ref name="Sabatino_1999">{{cite book |last=Di Sabatino |first=David |title=The Jesus People Movement: An Annotated Bibliography and General Resource |series=Bibliographies and Indexes in Religious Studies |volume=49 |year=1999 |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=[[Westport, CT]] |isbn=0-313-30268-5 |pages=16–17 |chapter=The Spiritual Sixties and the Jesus People Movement }}</ref> and came to be associated with the same, even though its primary attendees were not directly involved in that movement.<ref name="NYT_19720612"/>
It was held in various locations in [[Dallas, Texas]] from June 12 to June 17, 1972, with a nightly gathering in the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]]. Its goal was to gather 100,000 high school and college students together to train them in personal [[evangelism]], with a vision toward world evangelism, and to encourage attendees to seek some form of Christian service career.
==Background== Attendance at the daytime conference was estimated at 80,000, with about 95% from a white background,<ref name="NW_79_25"/> fewer than 3000 black attendees,<ref name="CYTY_16_20"/> and an international representation of 75 countries.<ref name="LIFE_72_25">{{cite journal |title=Rallying For Jesus: 80,000 jam Dallas for a Crusade called Explo '72 |date=1972-06-30 |journal=[[Life (magazine)|Life]] |volume=72 |issue=25 }}</ref> Most of these were middle class high school and college students.<ref name="NW_79_25"/>
The daily schedule included evangelism classes and seminars in the daytime, with hands-on exercises in the afternoon. Nightly events at Cotton Bowl features bands, well known preachers,<ref name="NYT_19720612"/> and pro players from various sporting teams.<ref name="CYTY_16_14">{{cite journal |title=Explo '72: The Long Haul |journal=[[Christianity Today]] |date=1972-04-14 |volume=16 |issue=14 |page=38 |issn=0009-5753}}</ref>
[[Billy Graham]] spoke on six different occasions during the event including the final event which was a public, eight-hour-long, [[Christian music festival]] on Saturday, June 17, 1972. Dubbed "The Christian Woodstock", the event drew an estimated attendance between 100,000 and 200,000. ''Newsweek'' described the crowds as being "militant Christians."<ref name="NW_79_25">{{cite journal |last=Woodward |first=Kenneth L. |title=The Christian Woodstock |page=52 |journal=[[Newsweek]] |volume=79 |issue=25 |date=1972-06-26 }}</ref> Featured artists were [[Love Song (band)|Love Song]], [[Larry Norman]], [[Randy Matthews]], [[The Archers (musical group)|The Archers]], [[Children of the Day]], [[Johnny Cash]], and [[Kris Kristofferson]]. The festival was held on a huge open swath of land just north of downtown Dallas that had been cleared for construction of the Woodall Rodgers Freeway. The excavation for this highway linking Interstate 35 and US75 would forever obliterate the festival site. Portions of this event were recorded and released on the 1972 album Jesus Sound Explosion. Included on the album were performances by artists as diverse as Johnny Cash, Andrae Crouch and The Disciples, Willa Dorsey, The Speer Family, and Armageddon Experience.
Many conservative Christian groups were critical of Explo '72 for its ecumenical involvement with both Protestant and Roman Catholic ministries, and for its use of rock music. The event attracted Jesus movement fringe groups, including the [[Children of God (cult)|Children of God]] and the [[Christian World Liberation Front]].<ref name="NYT_19720612">{{cite news |last=Fiske |first=Edward B. |title=A 'Religious Woodstock' Draws 75,000 |pages=A1, A19.5 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |volume= |issue= |date=1972-06-16 }}</ref><ref name="CYTY_16_20">{{cite journal |last=Plowman |first=Edward E. |title='Godstock' in Big D |journal=[[Christianity Today]] |date=1972-07-07 |volume=16 |issue=20 |pages=31–32 |issn=0009-5753}}</ref>
==Impact== The long-term impact of Explo '72 is difficult to measure. The most obvious and lasting effect was the influence of [[Jesus music]], which would later be more commonly called [[Contemporary Christian Music]]. At least one critic credits the event with spawning the entire [[Christian music industry]].<ref name="JJT_RBW_2000">{{cite book |last=Thompson |first=John J. |authorlink=John J. Thompson |title=Raised by Wolves |year=2000 |publisher=ECW Press |isbn=978-1-55022-421-4 |pages=79, 147–151, 234}}</ref>
[[Maynard Pittendreigh]], who attended the event as a recent high school graduate, did a limited study when working on his Master of Divinity degree in which he analyzed the long-term effects of large scale evangelistic events. Gathering information from churches from South Carolina that had sent youth groups to the event, he was able to demonstrate that more than 60% of those participants had entered the ordained ministry, were engaged in theological training, or had become missionaries.
David Hill Scott, writing for the May, 2005, edition of ''[[Christianity Today]]'', documented the effects Explo '72 had on [[Pope John Paul II]]. As a cardinal in Poland, the future Pope was heavily influenced toward evangelistic efforts by Joe Losiak, a Polish American student who had attended Explo '72 and introduced its concepts to Roman Catholic officials in Poland.
==References== {{reflist}} *[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/demonobsession666/explo72.html&date=2009-10-25+19:26:33 Excerpts from various magazines commenting on the event] *[http://www.one-way.org/lovesong/explo.htm Love Song's remembrances of the event]
;Extended resources<!-- organize by date --> *{{cite journal |last=Calomeni |first=Joe |author2=Sandy Stubblefield |title=Marching to Exlpo '72 |journal=Christian Life |date=June 1972 |volume=34 |issue=2 |pages=18–19, 122, 124 |issn=0009-5427}} *{{cite journal |last=Hill |first=Bob |title=To All The Nations... beginning at Dallas |journal=Christian Life |date=August 1972 |volume=34 |issue=4 |pages=20–23 |issn=0009-5427}} *{{cite journal |title=Photo Feature: Explo '72 |journal=Christian Life |date=August 1972 |volume=34 |issue=4 |pages= |issn=0009-5427}}
