{{Italicize title}} [[File:Logotipo Festival Internacional Cervantino - (Guanajuato) 07.JPG|thumbnail|right|Emblem of the festival in the streets of Guanajuato]] -The '''Festival Internacional Cervantino''' (FIC), popularly known as ''El Cervantino'', takes place each fall in the [[Guanajuato, Guanajuato|city of Guanajuato]], located in central [[Mexico]]. This is a small colonial-era city with history of having a large cultural scene. The origins of the festival are from the mid 20th century, when short plays by [[Miguel de Cervantes]] called ''[[entremés|entremeses]]'' (singular ''entremés'') were performed in the city’s plazas. In 1972, this was expanded with federal support to include more events to add a more international flavor. Since then, FIC has grown to become the most important international artistic and cultural event in Mexico and [[Latin America]], and one of four major events of its type in the world.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino:Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = 15–16}}</ref><ref name="sicgob">{{cite web |url= http://www.sic.gob.mx/ficha.php?table=festival&table_id=335|title= Festival Internacional Cervantino |work= Sistema de Información Cultural |publisher= CONACULTA |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |accessdate=September 10, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="38th">{{cite web|url=http://www.fundaciontelevisa.org/cultura/festival-internacional-cervantino-38a-edicion-2010.html |title=38 Festival Internacional Cervantino se suma a los festejos del Bicentenario y Centenario de nuestro país |publisher=Fundación Televisa |location=Mexico |trans-title=38th Festival Internacional Cervantino sums up the festivities of the Bicentennial and Centennial of our country |language=Spanish |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702065438/http://www.fundaciontelevisa.org/cultura/festival-internacional-cervantino-38a-edicion-2010.html |archivedate=July 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="acercade">{{cite web |url=http://www.festivalcervantino.gob.mx/Facebook/About |title=Acerca del Festival Internacional Cervantino 2011 |publisher=Festival Internacional Cervantino |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=About the Festival International Cervantino 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926022411/http://www.festivalcervantino.gob.mx/Facebook/About |archivedate=September 26, 2011 |df= }}</ref> It is a member of the [[European Festivals Association]] and the [[Asian Association of Theater Festivals]]<ref name="sicgob"/> In addition to government support, there are also private sponsors such as [[Telmex]], [[Televisa]] and [[Microsoft]].<ref name="38th"/>
==History==
===Origins through the 1970s=== [[File:Sankai Juku.jpg|thumb|Sankai Juku performing at the 2006 Festival]] The city of Guanajuato, where the Festival takes place, has historically had a large cultural scene in relation to its size. The richness of the mines in colonial times started a tradition of theaters and other cultural venues to satisfy the desires of the middle and upper classes. The city has a tradition of hosting musical, theatrical and dance events not only in its numerous theaters but also in its many small plazas with benches.<ref name="ficmexconnect">{{cite web |url= http://www.mexconnect.com/articles/623-the-festival-internacional-cervantino-in-guanajuato |title= The Festival Internacional Cervantino in Guanajuato |first=Ana |last=Cervantes |date=January 1, 2001 |publisher=Mexconnect newsletter |issn=1028-9089 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 }}</ref>
In 1953, Enrique Ruelas of the [[University of Guanajuato]] began to put on an annual event called the Entremeses de Miguel de Cervantes Saaevedra, short plays written by the author of [[Don Quixote]]. These plays are still part of the annual Festival. In 1972, he founded the Coloquio Cervantino from June to September to expand the annual Entremeses event.<ref name="acercade" /> Ruelas's efforts came to the attention of the federal government through actress [[Dolores del Río]]. While in the city of Guanajuato, she came across the Entremeses being performed at the Plaza San Roque and was fascinated. Around the same time, former president [[Luis Echeverría]] had attended cultural festivals in Europe and was interested in doing something similar in Mexico. Through Echeverría's cousin, Del Río relayed what she had seen in Guanajuato.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino: Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = 31–32}}</ref> The federal government then established the foundation for an international cultural festival, originally proposing it for [[Acapulco]]. However, the tradition of the Entremeses was the main reason why Guanajuato was eventually chosen, meshing the two ideas to produce the modern event for the first time in 1972 with performances by artists from fourteen countries including Mexico. For this reason, this year is considered the foundation of the event.<ref name="acercade"/>
The Festival in its current form was a governmental effort, with the 1972 edition attracting interest solely because of the influence of the politicians promoting it.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino: Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = |pages = 19}}</ref> The Cervantino had its greatest growth from 1976 to 1982, during the presidency of [[José López Portillo]] because of the efforts of his wife, Carmen Romano, who promoted it abroad.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino: Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = 15}}</ref> It quickly gained the attention of noted artists, with Berlin Philharmonic director [[Herbert von Karajan]] offering to appear at no cost.<ref name=":0" /> Initially the city of Guanajuato had difficulties in hosting the event due to the lack of infrastructure.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino:Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = |pages = 16}}</ref>
[[Elizabeth II]] and the [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]] attended the event in 1975. By decree, an organizing committee was set up in 1976 under the Secretaría de Educación Pública, the state and city of Guanajuato and the University of Guanajuato to invite artists from Mexico and abroad. Some of the first invited by this committee were [[Mario Moreno Cantinflas]] and [[Dolores del Río]]. This committee is still in charge today, working with the [[Consejo Nacional para la Cultura y las Artes]], el [[Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes]] and the Instituto de Cultura de [[Guanajuato]]. In 1978, [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Juan Carlos]] and [[Queen Sofía of Spain|Sofía of Spain]] attended as guests of honor.<ref name="acercade" />
Initially, the city of Guanajuato was only the host, with local artistic groups not participating in the event. However, efforts were soon made to lobby for their inclusion, especially by the Universidad de Guanajuato, and now artists from this university and other parts of the city and state regularly appear.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino:Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = 96–97}}</ref>
===1980s to the present=== Since 1982, the festival has diminished somewhat in size, mostly because of reduced funding. Another issue that arose was that the festival had become very popular with backpackers, who slept in the streets and caused problems for local residents.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino: Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = 51}}</ref> However, it remained a very important event, attracting notable acts and up to 140 journalists to cover it.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino: Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = 102}}</ref> In the 1980s, these included [[Lazar Berman]], [[Mercedes Sosa]], the [[New York Philharmonic]], [[Joan Baez]], [[Gilbert Bécaud]], [[Mario Lavista]], [[Guillermo Velázquez]], [[Los Leones de la Sierra de Xichú]], the [[National Ballet of Canada]], [[Alwin Nikolais|Nikolais Dance Theater]], the [[Bolshoi Ballet]], [[Sankai Juku]], [[Theater Scena STU]] (Poland) and the [[Marionette Theatre of Hungary]].<ref name="acercade"/>
In 1989, the city became a [[World Heritage Site]] which allowed most of the city’s colonial and late 19th-century architecture, including its theatres, to be restored.<ref name="ficmexconnect"/>
During the 1990s, the festival featured acts such as the [[Guitar Trio of Amsterdam]], [[Voices of Change]], the [[Vienna Quintet]], [[Guadalupe Pineda]], [[Krzysztof Jakowicz]], [[Krystyna Borucinska]], [[Kronos Quartet]], [[Madredeus]], the [[Open Theater of Belgrade]], the [[Lindsay Kemp]] Company and the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]].<ref name="acercade"/>
In the 2000s, the custom of having Mexican states and foreign countries and regions as “special guests” began. In 2001, the invited region was [[Oceania]] along with [[Veracruz]]. Acts featured during those years included [[Hélène Grimaud]], [[Eugenio Toussaint]], [[Juan Fornell and Los Van Van]], the [[Vienna Symphony|Vienna Symphony Virtuosi]], [[Enrique Bunbury]], [[Los Tigres del Norte]], [[Panteón Rococó]], [[Meno Fortas]] and [[Les 7 doigts de la main]].<ref name="acercade"/>
The city was declared the Cervantino Capital of America in 2005, which prompted the federal government to issue a commemorative silver coin.<ref name="acercade"/>
However, problems with the lack of funds and organizational issues brought the event to a crisis by 2006. There were structural and financial changes made during the rest of that decade, and by 2010, the Festival was able to recuperate much of its former status, attracting major artists from around the world.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino: Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = |isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = 51–52}}</ref> However, problems with large crowds of mostly young people, drinking in public remains a problem, especially for the local populace.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Festival Internacional Cervantino:Visiones de un mismo escenario|last = |first = |publisher = CONACULTA|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Mexico City|pages = 69–70}}</ref>
The 38th edition of the Festival in 2010 was dedicated to [[Celebration of Mexican political anniversaries in 2010|Mexico’s Bicentennial of Independence and Centennial of the Revolution]]. Three states, [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Michoacán]] and [[Querétaro]], along with three countries, [[Argentina]], [[Colombia]] and [[Chile]], were the special guests as they celebrated their bicentennials in the same year.<ref name="acercade" /> The 2010 version had 3,161 artists from 31 countries, with special emphasis on traditional Mexican music and dance.<ref name="38th" />
The 2011 version brought together 2,800 artists from 29 countries, in genres such as classical and folk music to [[techno]], open-air theatre, expositions, recent plays and other works from the 20th century by well-known writers.<ref name="farenheit">{{cite web |url= http://www.fahrenheitmagazine.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=1930:festival-internacional-cervantino-2011&lang=es |title=Festival Internacional Cervantino 2011 |date=June 22, 2011 |publisher=Fahrenheit Magazine |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |accessdate=September 10, 2011 }}</ref> It is dedicated to the environment, with a theme of “The Gifts of Nature” and special guests [[Denmark]], [[Finland]], [[Sweden]], [[Norway]] and [[Nayarit]].<ref name="anunican">{{cite news |title= Anuncian en Guanajuato programa del Festival Cervantino 2011 |url= http://www.informador.com.mx/cultura/2011/301663/6/anuncian-en-guanajuato-programa-del-festival-cervantino-2011.htm |newspaper=El Informador |location=Guadalajara, Mexico |date=June 22, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Announce in Guanajuato the program of the Festival Cervantino 2011 }}</ref><ref name="noruegaen">{{cite web |url= http://www.noruega.org.mx/News_and_events/Cervantino-2011/Noruega-en-el-Festival-Cervantino-2011/ |title= Noruega en el Festival Cervantino |year=2011 |publisher= Embajada Real de Noruega en México |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=Norway at the Festival Cervantino |accessdate=September 10, 2011 }}</ref> Artists include The [[Oslo Camerata]], [[Geir Henning Braaten]], [[Knut Reiersrud]], [[Mari Boine]],<ref name="noruegaen" /> a dramatization of ''[[Il Postino]]'' by [[Pablo Neruda]],<ref name="ilpostino">{{cite news |title= El Cervantino rendirá homenaje a Daniel Catán con la obra Il Postino |url= http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/cultura/66318.html |newspaper=El Universal |location=Mexico City |date=September 6, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Cervantino pay homage to Daniel Catán with the work Il Postino }}</ref> the [[Saint Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra]] focusing on 19th century Russian music, especially [[Tchaikovsky]],<ref name="orqsanpete">{{cite news |title= La Orquesta de San Petersburgo viene al Cervantino |url= http://eleconomista.com.mx/entretenimiento/2011/09/07/orquesta-san-petersburgo-viene-cervantino |agency=Notimex |newspaper=El Economista |location=Mexico City |date=September 7, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Orchestra of Saint Petersburg comes to the Cervantino }}</ref><ref name="musicarusa">{{cite news |title= Música rusa presente en el Festival Cervantino |url= http://www.aztecanoticias.com.mx/notas/cultura/70665/musica-rusa-presente-en-el-festival-cervantino |newspaper=Azteca Noticias |location=Mexico City |date=September 7, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Russian music present at the Festival Cervantino }}</ref> the [[DeMUG Baroque Ensemble]], and an exhibition of [[Oaxaca]]n painter [[Francisco Toledo]] in the Museo del Pueblo.<ref name="mostraran">{{cite news |title= Mostrarán en Festival Cervantino de Guanajuato obras inéditas de Toledo |url= http://www.e-oaxaca.mx/noticias/oaxaca-en-la-red/6012-mostraran-en-festival-cervantino-de-guanajuato-obras-ineditas-de-toledo.html |agency=La Jornada |newspaper=e-Oaxaca Noticias |location=Oaxaca |date=August 19, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Festival Cervantino of Guanajuato will show unedited Works by Toledo}}</ref> The 2011 event cost 122 million pesos to set up, with most of the money coming from [[CONACULTA]] and the rest from the state of [[Guanajuato]], the [[University of Guanajuato]] and the [[Guanajuato, Guanajuato|city of Guanajuato]].<ref name="anunican" />
The 2014 performance was opened by [[taiko]] drumming group [[Tokyo Dagekidan]], a performance attended by Japan's Prince [[Fumihito, Prince Akishino|Fumihito Akishino]] and his wife [[Kiko, Princess Akishino|Kiko]].<ref name=guardiola>{{cite news |author= Andrés Guardiola |title= Percusiones niponas y luz en el cielo inauguran el Cervantino |newspaper=Excelsior |location=Mexico City |date=October 9, 2014 |url= http://www.excelsior.com.mx/expresiones/2014/10/09/986059|accessdate=April 16, 2015}}</ref><ref name=efenews>{{cite news |title= Arranca Festival Cervantino con presencia del príncipe de Japón, Akishino: MÉXICO CERVANTINO |newspaper=EFE News Service |location=Madrid |date=October 9, 2014 }}</ref>
==Sites== [[File:Alhondiga-Granaditas-Mexico.JPG|thumb|left|View of the Alhondiga de Granaditas]] The events happen in the forty nine theatres, plazas and other venues in the city, with satellite events in other plazas in the state and other cities in the country.<ref name="38th"/> The Festival in the city of Guanajuato takes advantage of these numerous venues, indoor and outdoor which include the [[Teatro Juárez]], the [[Teatro Principal (Guanajuato)|Teatro Principal]], the [[Cervantes Theater|Teatro Cervantes]], the Patio of the Faculty of Industrial Relations, the State Auditorium, the Plaza San Roque, the Esplanade of the [[Alhóndiga de Granaditas|Alhondiga]], the [[Teatro de Minas]], the [[La Valenciana Church (San Cayetano)|Valenciana Church]] and the [[Ex-Hacienda of San Gabriel de Barrera]]. In addition, seven museum spaces are used for exhibitions such as those of photography.<ref name="ficmexconnect"/>
The event represents a tourist and economic windfall for the city, which brought in 423 million pesos in 2010, a 57% increase over 2009 with hotel occupancy alone up 39%. The total number of visitors in 2010 is estimated at 179,000, with 463,000 tickets to events sold. In addition to the events in Guanajuato proper, there were another 125,000 attendees to related activities in 37 cities and seventeen states in Mexico.<ref name="derrama">{{cite news |title= Creció derrama económica del Festival Internacional Cervantino |url= http://www.elporvenir.com.mx/notas.asp?nota_id=444468 |newspaper=El Porvenir |location=Mexico City |date=November 8, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Economic windfall from the Festival Internacional Cervantino grew }}</ref>
==Types of events== Being named after Spanish writer [[Miguel de Cervantes]], the Festival has a special emphasis on artistic creations in the Spanish language, with the original tradition of performing this writer’s “entremeses” plays upheld by the University Theater of Guanajuato. The international aspect is to create a space for discovery and exchange.<ref name="sicgob"/> The [[Ballet Folklorico de Mexico]] under [[Amalia Hernández]] has performed every year since the beginning.<ref name="acercade"/> Acts have been booked from all parts of the world of a wide variety from classical music, Mexican folk dance, [[Chinese variety art|Chinese acrobats]] and more.<ref name="ficmexconnect"/> The event attracts artists from all over the world each year in order to present typical aspects of culture from each country.<ref name="acercade"/> Acts include those from genres such as opera, music, dance, theatre, street spectaculars, visual arts, film and literature along with various academic events.<ref name="farenheit"/> The Festival has an agreement with the [[MUTEK|MUTEK Festival of Montreal]] with the aim of presenting newer acts to the audiences in Mexico especially in the field of electronic music.<ref name="38th"/>
==Other aspects== In 2010, the Presea FIC was instituted to recognize the work of Mexican and foreign artists for their contributions to culture. The prize is symbolized by a statue designed by Vicente Rojo, which is awarded during the opening ceremonies. The first was awarded to [[Luis Herrera de la Fuente]].<ref name="acercade"/><ref name="farenheit"/>
To promote a link between culture and technology, the Festival and Microsoft México sponsor a Technology Pavilion at the Mesón de San Antonio. It is planned to contain an Internet café with large lounge chairs and wireless services for those with mobile devices.<ref name="tecnologia">{{cite news |title= El Festival Cervantino presenta pabellón tecnológico |url= http://www.informador.com.mx/cultura/2010/241997/6/el-festival-cervantino-presenta-pabellon-tecnologico.htm |newspaper=El Informador |location=Guadalajara, Mexico |date=October 17, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Festival Cervantino presents technology pavilion }}</ref> Microsoft sponsors a set of academic lectures about what’s new in technology and art, games and everyday life.<ref name="jovenes">{{cite press release |title= El Festival Internacional Cervantino centra su mirada en actividades dedicadas a los jóvenes |publisher=CONACULTA |date=August 3, 2011 |url= http://www.conaculta.gob.mx/sala_prensa_detalle.php?id=14798 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Festival Internacional Cervantino centers its gaze in activities for youth |accessdate=September 10, 2011 }}</ref>
Much of the festival is set up to attract young people from children to university age. The Cervantino Program for Youth sponsors programs for this age group as well as other activities.<ref name="jovenes"/> It has an annual Artistic Creativity Contest for Youth put on in collaboration with the [[Edinburgh International Festival]] and [[The Anglo Mexican Foundation]].<ref name="presentan">{{cite news |title= Presentan el programa del festival Cervantino dedicado a los jóvenes |url= http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2011/08/04/cultura/a06n3cul |newspaper=La Jornada |location=Mexico City |date=August 4, 2011 |page=6 |accessdate=September 10, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The program of the Festival Cervantino dedicated to youth is presented}}</ref> Two activities in 2010 were a contest of photos taken with cell phones and another contest of short electronic music pieces, both of which were launched over the Internet. Winners received trips to the [[Edinburgh International Festival]], the first and largest international cultural event of its type in the world.<ref name="38th"/><ref name="jovenes"/> A number of performers and academic activities are scheduled with young audiences in mind. These include rock and electronic music concerts with dance and theater events. In 2011, these included German electronic music groups [[Moonbootica]] and [[Schlachthofbronx]] sponsored by the [[Goethe Institute]] and rock musicians [[Sierra León]], [[Finde]], [[El Otro Yo]] and [[Rubick]] .<ref name="jovenes"/><ref name="presentan"/> Theatre for youth include [[Vivarium Studio]] performing L éffet de Serge, [[Mauricio García Lozano]] and [[Teatro Farfullero]] presenting La pequeña habitación al final de la escalera and [[Circo Aereo]] and [[Les Objets Volants]], a [[Finns|Finnish]]/French group with acrobats, comedians and other circus performers. Other events for youth include [[DJ Frivolous]] and [[DJ Kid Koala]] from Canada and German artist [[Brandt Brauer Frick]] who mixes electronic and acoustic sounds.<ref name="jovenes"/> University students can get up to a 73% discount on tickets for selected acts.<ref name="presentan"/> There is an event to bring together children and Mexican poets and a performance of A magic flute for children by the French ensamble [[Théâtre des Bouffes du Nord]].<ref name="farenheit"/>
In 2011, the Festival scheduled its first Art Book Fair, focusing on books about the visual and theatrical arts.<ref name="farenheit"/>
Based on the program sponsored by the [[Lucerne Festival]], the Cervantino Academy’s purpose is to train professional level instrumentalists in classical and contemporary music.<ref name=42nd>{{cite book |title= Programa 42nd Festival Internacional Cervantino |year=2014 |publisher= Secretaría de Educación Pública, State of Guanajuato and CONACULTA |page=127}}</ref><ref name=aflores>{{cite news |author=Alondra Flores |title= Jóvenes músicos reciben clases magistrales de célebres invitados al festival Cervantino |newspaper=La Jornada |location=Mexico City |date=October 17, 2014 |page=6 |url= http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2014/10/17/cultura/a06n1cul |accessdate=March 15, 2015 }}</ref> The program sponsors individual students, classes, workshops, practice sessions and concerts, including at the Festival Cervantino, both by small ensembles as well as in an orchestra. Participants are under thirty and are selected by audition. The program has invited maestros from both Mexico and abroad, including [[Irvine Arditti]], [[Steve Schick]], [[Norio Sato]] and [[Salvatore Sciarrino]].<ref name=42nd/><ref name=aflores/><ref name=reforzar>{{cite news |title= El Cervantino busca reforzar repertorio contemporáneo con Academia |newspaper=El Informador |location=Guadalajara |date=October 11, 2014 |url= http://www.informador.com.mx/cultura/2014/553394/6/el-cervantino-busca-reforzar-repertorio-contemporaneo-con-academia.htm |accessdate=March 15, 2015 }}</ref> The program attracts students from various countries in Latin America, including [[Guatemala]], Brazil, Cuba, and [[Bolivia]] as well as Mexico.<ref name=aflores/><ref name=reforzar/>
==Festival events for audiences outside of Guanajuato== Prior Festival events and shows related to artists scheduled to perform in upcoming festivals are shown through the Festival’s television, radio and website. A channel called TV FIC or Canal Cervantino was created on channel 157 of [[Cablevision (Mexico)|Cablevision]] to broadcast archived footage of past festivals and performances by those scheduled to perform the upcoming year.<ref name="38th"/><ref name="acercade"/> [[Microsoft]] sponsors the Festival’s web page as well as an online radio station called Radio FIC which offers online archives of music, video and photographic works, as well as a various types of informative material.<ref name="38th"/>
Most of the events related to the Festival occur in Guanajuato, but some events such as dance, plays and concerts are presented live or are transmitted to other areas of the country. These include national and international acts.<ref name=balvarez>{{cite news |author=Benjamin Alvarez |title= Más allá de Guanajuato |newspaper=Terra Noticias |url= http://deportes.terra.com.mx/mas-alla-de-guanajuato,aa166cfb8ebf8410VgnCLD200000b2bf46d0RCRD.html |accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name=criterio>{{cite news|title=Festival Cervantino llegará a todos los estados del país |newspaper=Criterio |location=Hidalgo |date=October 11, 2014 |url=http://www.criteriohidalgo.com/notas.asp?id=269173 |accessdate=March 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402103234/http://www.criteriohidalgo.com/notas.asp?id=269173 |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }}</ref> The Más Allá de Guanajuato (Beyond Guanajuato) program to bring Cervantino cultural events to other parts of the country, free to the public. As of 2014, the program has sponsored events in over 100 venues in 26 states and the Federal District. These include schools, cultural center, libraries and correctional institutions.<ref name="42nd p140">{{cite book |title= Programa 42nd Festival Internacional Cervantino |year=2014 |publisher= Secretaría de Educación Pública, State of Guanajuato and CONACULTA |page=140}}</ref> Much of this activity is made possible through a collaboration with CONACULTA and the Secretaría de Educación Pública.<ref name=mimorelia>{{cite web|title=Michoacán formará parte del 42 Festival Internacional Cervantino con seis actividades gratuitas |work=Mi Morelia |publisher=Trade Web S. de R.L. de C.V |date=October 6, 2014 |url=http://www.mimorelia.com/noticias/cultura/michoacan-formara-parte-del-42-festival-internacional-cervantino-con-seis-actividades-gratuitas/150783 |accessdate=March 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402130646/http://www.mimorelia.com/noticias/cultura/michoacan-formara-parte-del-42-festival-internacional-cervantino-con-seis-actividades-gratuitas/150783 |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }}</ref>
The Ruelos Project, named after the founder of the Entremeses Cervantinos, was created in 2014 to pair artists with disadvantaged communities. The Festival provides logistical support but the actors and support staff are locals with that thirty participants in each event.<ref name="42nd p128–129}">{{cite book |title= Programa 42nd Festival Internacional Cervantino |year=2014 |publisher= Secretaría de Educación Pública, State of Guanajuato and CONACULTA |pages=128–129}}</ref> The project is based on the original Entremeses Cervantinos done by Enrique Ruelos starting in the 1950s which relied on community participation to produce plays such as those by Shakespeare but modified to the local culture. The performances are planned and executed with communities where there are high levels of crime and family instability and violence, mostly in the state of Guanajuato.<ref name=createatro>{{cite news |author=Sonia Avila |title= El Festival Internacional Cervantino crea teatro comunitario |newspaper=Excelsior |location=Mexico City |date=April 29, 2014 |url= http://www.excelsior.com.mx/expresiones/2014/04/29/956368 |accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref> They have also worked with prison populations.<ref name=cereso>{{cite news |title= Internos del Cereso escenifican a Hamlet |newspaper= Union Guanajuato/El Universal |location=Guanajuato/Mexico City |date=October 24, 2014 |url= http://www.unionguanajuato.mx/articulo/2014/10/24/cultura/internos-del-cereso-escenifican-hamlet |accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref>
==Noted performers at the event==

{{about|the former theatre in London, named, for a time, the Charing Cross Theatre|for the nearby music hall of that name|Charing Cross Music Hall|the theatre of the same name in Kansas City|Folly Theater}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use British English|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox Theatre |name = Folly Theatre |image = Follyprog.jpg |caption = Folly Theatre, programme from 1878–79 season |address = William IV Street |city = [[City of Westminster|Westminster]], [[London]] |country = |designation = ''Demolished'' |coordinates = {{coord|51.507466|-0.122981|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |architect = Bradwell and Field |owner = [[John Lawrence Toole]] |capacity = 900 |type = [[Music hall]] and playhouse |opened = |yearsactive = 1869 - 1895 |rebuilt = 1869 Arthur Evers
1876 [[Thomas Verity]]
1882 J. J. Thompson |closed = |othernames = 1840 Lowther Rooms
1848 The London Oratory
1855 Polygraphic Hall
1869 Charing Cross Theatre
1876 Folly Theatre
1882 Toole's Theatre |production = |currentuse = Police station (on site) |website = }} The '''Folly Theatre''' was a [[London]] theatre of the late 19th century, in William IV Street, near [[Charing Cross]], in the [[City of Westminster]]. It was converted from the house of a religious order, and became a small theatre, with a capacity of 900 seated and standing. The theatre specialised in presenting [[music hall]], [[Victorian burlesque|burlesque]] and [[opera bouffe]]. The [[Beefsteak Club]] had quarters above the theatre. As a stock company, under the direction first of Alexander Henderson and [[Lydia Thompson]] and then of [[John Lawrence Toole]], the theatre was significant for beginning the professional careers of many [[Victorian era]] actors, writers and actor-managers. The theatre was demolished in 1895, possibly due to disturbance caused to the neighbouring [[Charing Cross Hospital]]. ==History== ===Early years=== The building opened as the ''Lowther Rooms''Named for the nearby popular ''Lowther Arcade'', a covered market for fancy goods, some 250 feet long and considered at that time ''one of the sights of London'' in [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=45140 ''Charing Cross, the railway stations, and Old Hungerford Market'', Old and New London: Volume 3 (1878), pp. 123-134] accessed: 16 October 2007 in 1840. It was the residence of the ''[[Oratory of Saint Philip Neri|Fathers of the London Oratory of St. Philip Neri]]'' from 1848–56 and was used for lectures. Here, in 1850, [[John Henry Newman]] delivered his ''Lectures on Anglican Difficulties'', after his conversion to Catholicism.[http://www.newmanreader.org/works/anglicans/volume1/index.html ''Certain Difficulties Felt by Anglicans in Catholic Teaching'' John Henry Newman] accessed 11 Oct 2007 On the departure of the religious order, which moved to the ''[[Brompton Oratory]]'', the hall became ''Woodin's Polygraphic Hall'' in 1855, where William S. Woodin gave monologue entertainments.[http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Toole.htm ''Toole's Theatre-Polygraphic Hall-Charing Cross Theatre-The Folly'' (Arthur Lloyd)] accessed 11 Oct 2007 In 1869, the building was converted to a small [[Music hall]] and playhouse called the ''Royal Charing Cross Theatre'' and, in 1872 was renamed the '''Charing Cross Theatre''' and was advertised as the Theatre Royal, Charing Cross, in 1874-75.[http://www.victorianlondon.org/entertainment/follytheatre.htm "Victorian London - Entertainment and Recreation" from VictorianLondon.org] accessed 11 Oct 2007 The theatre opened on 19 June 1869 with [[W. S. Gilbert]]'s [[Victorian burlesque|burlesque]] of ''[[Norma (opera)|Norma]]'', called ''[[The Pretty Druidess]]'', on the bill,[http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/other_gilbert/pretty_druidess/review.html Review of the theatre's opening night,] ''[[The Times]]'' (republished at the Gilbert and Sullivan Archive) and in 1870 it held Gilbert and [[Frederic Clay]]'s ''[[The Gentleman in Black]]''. In 1872, it hosted J. S. Clarke's revival of [[Richard Brinsley Sheridan|Sheridan]]'s ''[[The Rivals]]'', featuring Mrs Stirling in the role that was to make her famous as ''[[Mrs Malaprop]]''.[http://www.victorianweb.org/mt/theaters/pva234.html ''Theatres in Victorian London'' Philip V. Allingham (The Victorian Web)] accessed 11 Oct 2007 The name ''[[Charing Cross Music Hall]]'' was also adopted in the late 1880s by the brothers Carlo and Giovanni Gatti for their ''Gatti's-Under-the-Arches Music hall''. This became the Hungerford Music Hall in 1883, later returning to the former name.[http://www.collectbritain.co.uk/personalisation/object.cfm?uid=014EVA000000000U04008000 ''Advertisement for the Grand Star Company for Xmas at the Charing Cross Music Hall'' Collect Britain (British Library)] accessed 11 Oct 2007 ===Folly Theatre=== After some rebuilding, by architect [[Thomas Verity]], the theatre was renamed ''The Folly Theatre'' in 1876, when it was bought by Alexander Henderson, and it became a [[Victorian burlesque|burlesque]] house, with his wife, [[Lydia Thompson]], in the lead roles. The first piece was a successful burlesque of ''Blue Beard''.Gänzl, Kurt. ''Lydia Thompson, Queen of Burlesque'' (2002) Routledge {{ISBN|0-415-93766-3}} In 1877, ''Up the River, or the Strict Kew-Tea'', by [[H. B. Farnie]] and [[Robert Reece]] played at the theatre[http://www.operetta-research-center.org/main.php?task=archart&cat=4&sub_cat=10&id=00090 Information from the Operetta Research Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727081746/http://www.operetta-research-center.org/main.php?task=archart&cat=4&sub_cat=10&id=00090 |date=27 July 2011 }} accessed 11 Oct 2007 as did a Farnie and Reece adaptation of Offenbach called ''The Creole''.Adams, William Davenport. ''A Dictionary of the Drama (1904)'' 1904 Chatto & Windus, London In 1878, the theatre had a tremendous success with [[Violet Cameron]] in [[Robert Planquette]]'s ''[[Les cloches de Corneville]]'', adapted by Farnie and Reece, which (after transferring to the [[Globe Theatre (Newcastle Street)|Globe Theatre]] and returning to the Folly), held the record for long runs in [[musical theatre]] for a decade. [[Florence St. John]] got her start in the piece on tour and then in the theatre. Farnie and Reece's burlesque ''Stars and Garters'' then played. Reece's successful burlesque, ''Carmen; or Sold for a Song'', and [[Sydney Grundy]]'s ''After Long Years'' both played at the theatre in 1879. [[T. W. Roberton]]'s ''Dublin Bay'' played here in 1880. The theatre was described in ''[[Charles Dickens, Jr.|Dickens Dictionary of London]]'' (1879) as ''A little bandbox of a place, very prettily fitted up, and with a decided speciality for burlesque and opera bouffe''.[http://www.victorianlondon.org/entertainment/follytheatre.htm Charles Dickens (Jr.), ''Dickens's Dictionary of London'', 1879] accessed 11 Oct 2007 [[File:Farr Florence.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Florence Farr]] at the theatre]] On 7 November 1879, [[John Lawrence Toole]] (1830-1906) took over the management, with a stock company. Presentations included [[farces]], burlesques and travesties of popular plays, beginning with [[Henry James Byron|H. J. Byron]]'s ''A Fool and His Money''.[https://books.google.com/books?id=1_MgAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA118&lpg=PA118&dq=%22toole's+theatre%22+london&source=web&ots=RswaSeZitb&sig=1nXzaz8MkEHRr1BPfdbu6LkOdb0 MacMichael, J. Holden.] ''The Story of Charing Cross and Its Immediate Neighbourhood'' (1906) Chatto & Windus, accessed 12 October 2007 Toole's only son, Frank, died on 7 December 1879 following an earlier football injury from which he never fully recovered.[http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchivePressText2003/20030503.html Culme, quoting ''The Sketch'', 13 December 1879] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703222809/http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchivePressText2003/20030503.html |date=3 July 2007 }}, accessed 12 October 2007 Toole was both a noted comedian and a friend of [[Charles Dickens]]. He spent much of the next few years touring, but also produced plays at the theatre, including [[Arthur Wing Pinero]]'s ''Hester's Mystery'' (1880) and Byron's ''Upper Crust and Auntie'' (1880),[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1880/04/26/98896595.pdf NY Times review of ''The Upper Crust and Auntie'' 26 April 1880] accessed 11 Oct 2007 [[Dion Boucicault]]'s play, ''Dot'', starring Toole, was produced here in 1881.[http://library.kent.ac.uk/library/special/Programmes/boucprog.htm Information from the play's programme] accessed 11 Oct 2007 ===Toole's Theatre=== In 1882, after further rebuilding, Toole re-opened the theatre as '''Toole's Theatre''', becoming the first actor to have a [[West End theatre]] named after him.Obituary: John Lawrence Toole, ''[[The Times]]'', 31 July 1906, p. 5 Noted actress [[Florence Farr]] (1860-1917) began her professional career with an apprenticeship at Toole's theatre, débuting with a juvenile role in Byron's ''Uncle Dick's Darling'', in 1882.{{cite web|url = https://drum.umd.edu/dspace/handle/1903/1530 | author = Boisseau, Robin Jackson | title = The Women of the Abbey Theatre, 1879-1925 | publisher = University of Maryland | date = 2004-05-05 | accessdate = 2007-10-11}} In 1883, ''Stage Dora; or, Who Killed Cock Robin'', a burlesque by [[F. C. Burnand]] of Sardou's ''Fédora'', premiered at Toole's, starring Toole. Burnand's ''Paw Claudian'' (1884) was a burlesque of the 1883 costume (Byzantine) drama 'Claudian' by Henry Herman and W. G. Wills. ''Mr. Guffin’s Elopement'' and ''The Great Tay-Kin'', two shows with words by [[Arthur Law (playwright)|Arthur Law]] and music by [[George Grossmith]], starring Toole, played at the theatre in 1885.{{cite book|last=Grossmith|first=George|year=1888|title=A Society Clown: Reminiscences|location=Bristol/London|publisher=Arrowsmith}} Chapter 8 [http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/books/grossmith/gg08.html Available online here] The last play by [[John Maddison Morton]] to be produced in his lifetime, a three-act farcical comedy called ''Going It'', played at Toole's in 1885 and kept the house in a continual roar of laughter.[[Clement Scott|Scott, Clement]], "Biographical Introduction" to [[John Maddison Morton|Morton, John Maddison]], ''Plays for Home Performance''. London: Ward, Lock and Co., 1889, p. xiv. Pinero's ''Girls and Boys'' played here in 1885, as did ''[[Billee Taylor]]'' in 1886 and ''The Butler'', by [[Herman Charles Merivale]], starring Toole, also in 1886. ''Pepita'', an operetta by [[Charles Lecocq]], premiered at the theatre in 1888. ''The Don'', by Merivale, also starred Toole in 1888. [[File:Bungalowtoole.jpg|left|350px]]''The Bungalow'', by Fred Horner, played at the theatre in 1890.[http://www.21citizen.org.uk/catalogues/evanion/results.asp?key=Toole's+Theatre&source=showlist.asp&type=Heading&searchtype=&id=234 Notices and posters for Toole's Theatre pieces] ''Ibsen's Ghost'', a one-act parody on ''[[Ghosts (play)|Ghosts]]'', starring [[Irene Vanbrugh]] and Toole, was [[J. M. Barrie]]'s first London play, running for just 27 performances at Toole's Theatre from 30 May 1891. In 1892, Toole directed the première of Barrie's first hit play, ''Walker, London'', which ran for 497 performances.[http://www.c20th.com/ppjmbarrie.htm Peter Pan exhibition site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070220200635/http://www.c20th.com/ppjmbarrie.htm |date=20 February 2007 }} Toole retired in 1893, due to increasing ill health, brought on by the deaths within a few years of his family. His last piece was ''Thoroughbred'' by Ralph Lumley, and upon his retirement [[Rutland Barrington]] replaced him in the role.Barrington, Rutland (1908). ''Rutland Barrington: A Record of 35 Years' Experience on the English Stage, By Himself'', p. 100 The theatre was taken over by [[Violet Melnotte]], who had made her début at the Folly Theatre in October 1876 as ''Fezz'' in ''[[Bluebeard]]'' with Lydia Thompson's Company. She had many interests and at the same time was building the [[Duke of York's Theatre]], with her husband [[Frank Wyatt (singer)|Frank Wyatt]].[http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/whowaswho/M/MelnotteViolet.htm ''Violet Melnotte (1855-1935)'' D'Oyly Carte, Who Was Who (Boise State University)] accessed 11 Oct 2007 The lease expired in 1895 and plans were drawn up by [[Charles J. Phipps|C. J. Phipps]] to rebuild the theatre, but they were opposed, apparently because the noise at the theatre disturbed patients at the [[Charing Cross Hospital]]. The theatre was demolished in 1896Earl, John and Michael Sell. ''Guide to British Theatres 1750-1950'', pp. 250 (Theatres Trust, 2000) {{ISBN|0-7136-5688-3}} and the site used to extend Charing Cross Hospital.[http://www.library.rochester.edu/index.cfm?page=1169 ''Papers: Toole, John Lawrence'' (University of Rochester)] accessed 11 Oct 2007 The site is now a part of the Charing Cross Police Station. ==References== [[File:Taykinposter.JPG|right|thumb|Poster for ''The Great Tay-Kin'' at the theatre in 1885]] {{Reflist|33em}} [[Category:Former theatres in London]] [[Category:Former buildings and structures in the City of Westminster]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1840]] [[Category:1895 disestablishments in England]] [[Category:Former music hall venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Charles J. Phipps buildings]] [[Category:19th century in London]]

[[File:Hen chicken.jpg|thumb|Forced molting typically involves the removal of food and/or water from poultry for an extended period of time to reinvigorate egg-laying.]] '''Forced molting''', sometimes known as '''induced molting''', is the practice by some poultry industries of artificially provoking a flock to [[Molting|molt]] simultaneously, typically by withdrawing food for 7–14 days and sometimes also withdrawing water for an extended period. Forced molting is usually implemented when egg-production is naturally decreasing toward the end of the first egg-laying phase. During the forced molt, the birds cease producing eggs for at least two weeks, which allows the bird's reproductive tracts to regress and rejuvenate. After the molt, the hen's egg production rate usually peaks slightly lower than the previous peak, but egg quality is improved. The purpose of forced molting is therefore to increase egg production, egg quality, and profitability of flocks in their second or subsequent laying phases, by not allowing the hen's body the necessary time to rejuvenate during the natural cycle of feather replenishment.
The practice is controversial. While it is widespread in the US, it is prohibited in the EU.<ref name="Wigley">{{cite web|url=https://www.ciwf.org.uk/includes/documents/cm_docs/2013/s/salmonella.pdf|publisher=Compassion in World Farming|title=Salmonella|author=Wigley, P.|year=2013}}</ref>
==Background== Commercial hens usually begin laying eggs at 16–20 weeks of age, although production gradually declines soon after from approximately 25 weeks of age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hyline.com/Redbook/Performance/Gray_All.pdf|title=Performance Records of Hy-Line Grey |accessdate=November 18, 2011}}</ref> This means that in many countries, by approximately 72 weeks of age, flocks are considered economically unviable and are slaughtered after approximately 12 months of egg production,<ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite web|url=http://www.ciwf.org.uk/farm_animals/poultry/egg_laying_hens/default.aspx |title=Compassion in World Farming - Egg laying hens |publisher=Ciwf.org.uk |accessdate=August 26, 2011}}</ref> although chickens will naturally live for 6 or more years. However, in some countries, rather than being slaughtered, the hens are force molted to re-invigorate egg-laying for a second, and sometimes subsequent, laying phase.
Forced molting simulates the natural process where [[chicken]]s grow a new set of [[feather]]s in the Autumn, a process generally accompanied by a sharp reduction or cessation of egg production. Natural molting is stimulated by shortening day lengths combined with stress (of any kind). Before confinement housing with artificial lights was the norm, the Autumn molt caused a seasonal scarcity of eggs and high market prices. Farmers attempted to pamper their flocks to prevent the molt as long as possible, to take advantage of the high prices. Modern controlled-environment confinement housing has the opposite problem; the hens are not normally presented with sufficient stress or cues to go into molt naturally. However, after laying almost daily for nearly a year, their rate of egg production declines, as does the quality of the [[eggshell]] and the egg contents. In addition, the hens are overweight.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}}
It is sometimes claimed that forced molting is an artifact of modern intensive farming, but the practice predates the [[vertical integration]] of the poultry industry by decades; former Head of the Poultry Science Department at the University of Maryland, [[Morley A. Jull]] prescribes a precise molting program in his 1938 book, ''[[Poultry]] [[Husbandry]]''.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jull, M.A.|title=Poultry Husbandry|edition=2|year=1938|publisher=McGraw-Hill}}</ref>
==Methods== For a complete recovery of the reproductive tract, the hen's body weight must drop by 30 to 35 percent during the forced molt. This is typically achieved by withdrawing the hen's feed for 7–14 days, sometimes up to 28 days.<ref name="Molino et al., (2009)">{{cite journal |author=Molino, A.B. |author2=Garcia, E.A. |author3=Berto, D.A. |author4=Pelícia, K. |author5=Silva, A.P. |author6=Vercese F.|year=2009|title=The effects of alternative forced-molting methods on the performance and egg quality of commercial layers|journal=Brazilian Journal of Poultry Science|volume=11|pages=109–113 |doi=10.1590/s1516-635x2009000200006}}</ref> This induces the birds to lose their feathers, cease to lay eggs and lose body-weight.<ref name="Webster, (2003)">{{cite journal|author=Webster, A.B.|year=2003|title=Physiology and behavior of the hen during induced moult|journal=Poultry Science|volume=82|pages=992–1002|doi=10.1093/ps/82.6.992|pmid=12817455}}</ref><ref name="Duncan2010">{{cite book|editor=Duncan, I.J. |editor2=Hawkins, P.|year=2010|title=The Welfare of Domestic Fowl and Other Captive Birds|volume=9|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media}}</ref> Some programs combine feed withdrawal with a period of water withdrawal. Most programs also restrict the amount of lighting to provide a daylight period that is too short to stimulate egg production, providing a simulated autumn, the natural time of molt and minimum egg production.
Forced molting programs sometimes follow other variations. Some do not eliminate feed altogether, but may induce a molt by providing a low-density diet (e.g. grape pomace, cotton seed meal, [[alfalfa]] meal)<ref name="Patwardhan and King, (2011)">{{cite journal|author=Patwardhan, D. |author2=King, A.|year=2011|title=Review: feed withdrawal and non feed withdrawal moult|journal=World's Poultry Science Journal|volume=67|pages=253–268|doi=10.1017/s0043933911000286}}</ref> or dietary manipulation to create an imbalance of a particular nutrient(s). The most important among these include manipulation of minerals including [[sodium]], [[calcium]], [[iodine]] and [[zinc]], with full or partially reduced dietary intakes.<ref name="Khan et al., (2011)">{{cite journal|author=Khan, R.U. |author2=Nikousefat, Z. |author3=Javdani, M. |author4=Tufarelli, V. |author5=Laudadio, V. |year=2011|title=Zinc-induced moulting: production and physiology|journal=World's Poultry Science Journal|volume=67|pages=497-506|doi=10.1017/S0043933911000547}}</ref> These alternative methods of forced molting have not been widely used by the egg industries.<ref name="Duncan2010" />
In 2003, more than 75% of all flocks in the US were molted.<ref name="Yousaf and Chaudhry, (2008)">{{cite journal|author=Yousaf, M. |author2=Chaudhry, A.S.|year=2008|title=History, changing scenarios and future strategies to induce moulting in laying hens|journal=World's Poultry Science Journal|volume=64|pages=65–75|doi=10.1017/s0043933907001729}}</ref>
==Mortality== Some birds die during forced molting and it has been recommended that the flock must be managed so that mortality does not exceed 1.25% over the 1–2 weeks of (nearly complete) feed withdrawal, compared to a 0.5% to 1.0% monthly mortality in a well-managed flock under low-stress conditions.<ref name="North1990">{{cite book|author=North, M.O. |author2=Bell, D.D.|title=Commercial Chicken Production Manual|edition=4|year=1990|publisher=Van Nostrand Reinhold|pages=438}}</ref> Alternative methods of forced molting which do not use total food withdrawal, e.g. creating a dietary mineral imbalance, generally result in lower mortality rates.<ref name="Duncan2010" />
== Controversy == Temporary starvation of the hens is considered by many to be inhumane as well as a form of animal cruelty, and is the main objection of critics and opponents of the practice.
While forced molting is widespread in the US, it is prohibited in the EU.<ref name="Wigley">{{cite web|url=https://www.ciwf.org.uk/includes/documents/cm_docs/2013/s/salmonella.pdf|publisher=Compassion in World Farming|title=Salmonella|author=Wigley, P.|year=2013}}</ref> In the UK, the [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]] (Defra) states ''In no circumstances may birds be induced to moult by withholding feed and water.''<ref name="Defra">{{cite web|url=http://www.defra.gov.uk/publications/files/pb7274-laying-hens-020717.pdf|title=Code of Recommendations for the Welfare of Livestock: Laying Hens|year=2002|publisher=Defra}}</ref> Forced molting is not a common practice in Canada, where the animal welfare issues associated with it have rendered it basically obsolete.{{clarification needed|date=January 2015}}
Forced molting increases plasma [[corticosterone]] which, along with related hormones, decreases the levels of circulating [[lymphocyte]]s and other [[leukocyte]]s, thereby reducing the effectiveness of the bird's immune system. This means that birds being force molted become susceptible to disease, particularly ''[[Salmonella]]'' infections, and may produce contaminated eggs thereby compromising public health.<ref name="Santos2015">{{cite journal|author=Santos, I.C.L. |author2=Teixeira, R.S.C. |author3=Lopes, E.S. |author4=Albuquerque, A.H. |author5=Rocha e Silva, R.C. |author6=Salles, R.P.R. |author7=Maciel, W.C. |year=2015|title=Experimental infection of Salmonella Enteritidis in quails submitted to forced molting by feed fasting|journal=Revista Brasileira de Ciência Avícola|volume=17|issue=1|pages=31–36 |doi=10.1590/1516-635x170131-36}}</ref><ref name="Hald">{{cite journal|author=Hald, T. |author2=Nørrung, B. |author3=Chriél, M.|year=2010|title=Scientific opinion on a quantitative estimation of the public health impact of setting a new target for the reduction of Salmonella in laying hens|journal=EFSA Journal|volume=8|issue=4|pages=1546|doi=10.2903/j.efsa.2010.1546}}</ref><ref name="Webster2005">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepoultrysite.com/articles/489/nonfeed-withdrawal-molting/|author=Webster. A.B.|year=2005|publisher=The Poultry Site|accessdate=July 4, 2016|title=Non-feed withdrawal molting}}</ref><ref name="Denagamage">{{cite journal|author=Denagamage, T. |author2=Jayarao, B. |author3=Patterson, P. |author4=Wallner-Pendleton, E. |author5=Kariyawasam, S.|year=2015|title=Risk factors associated with Salmonella in laying hen farms: systematic review of observational studies|journal=Avian Diseases|volume=59|issue=2|pages=291–302 |doi=10.1637/10997-120214-reg}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.upc-online.org/molting/52703.htm The Animal Welfare and Food Safety Issues Associated With the Forced Molting of Laying Birds (United Poultry Concerns)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051230184816/http://www.ces.ncsu.edu/depts/poulsci/tech_manuals/induced_molting_management.html Induced Molting as a Management Tool (North Carolina State University)]

{{Infobox recurring event | name = <!--Uses page name if omitted--> | logo = [[File:Illinoisstatefair.JPG|frameless]] | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | genre = State fair | date = | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annually | venue = | location = [[Springfield, Illinois]] | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | country = | years_active = | first = {{Start date and age|1853|df=y}} | founder_name = | last = | prev = August 9 - 19, 2018 | next = August 2019 | participants = | attendance = | area = | budget = | activity = | patron = | organised = <!--"organized=" also works--> | filing = <!-- Filing status --> | people = | member = | sponsor = | website = {{URL|agr.state.il.us/isf/}} | footnotes = }}
The '''Illinois State Fair''' is an annual festival, centering on the theme of [[agriculture]], hosted by the [[U.S. state]] of [[Illinois]] in the state capital, [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]]. The [[state fair]] has been celebrated almost every year since 1853. In 2018 369,144 visits were tallied.<ref name="SJR">{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=2018 Illinois State Fair attendance down 8% from 2017 |url=http://www.sj-r.com/news/20180907/2018-illinois-state-fair-attendance-down-8-from-2017 |work= [[State Journal-Register]] |location=[[Springfield, Illinois]] |date=September 7, 2018 |access-date=September 7, 2018 }}</ref> This marked a sharp decline from the more than 700,000 visitors counted in 2008, when the fair had been the 13th largest state fair in the United States.<ref name = "Robert">{{cite news | last = Robert | first = Amanda | title = Prizewinner: Illinois State Fair makes $40 million for Springfield | publisher = [[Illinois Times]] | date = 2009-08-13 | url = http://illinoistimes.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A10757 | accessdate = 2009-08-17 }}</ref> Currently, the fair is held annually at the [[Illinois State Fairgrounds]] over an 11-day period in mid-August of each year. In 2018, the State Fair was held from August 9-19, and an admission fee was charged.
==History== The first Illinois State Fair was celebrated in 1853 in Springfield. In that first year, the admission fee was 25 cents. The fair moved to Chicago in 1855.<ref name="History">{{cite news | last = Robert | first = Amanda | title = A fair start, 156 years in the making | publisher = [[Illinois Times]] | date = 2009-08-13 | url = http://illinoistimes.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A10744 | accessdate = 2009-08-17 }}</ref> The 1850s were a golden age of agricultural [[journalism]], with a wide variety of editors offering many suggestions, well-founded or not, to increase [[farm]] productivity. The first State Fairs, in Illinois and other states, were created and organized by farmers in order to compare notes with their colleagues and distinguish between good and bad advice. [[File:Illinois State Fair.jpg|thumb|The Illinois State Fair - from Farm Home Newspaper 1916]]
During the years after the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], the rules of agricultural judging became standardized, and more and more farmers began to show their farm products. Increasing knowledge of genetics inspired the breeding and showing of [[purebred]] farm animals at both [[county fair]]s and the Illinois State Fair.
In the first half of the 20th century, the [[internal combustion engine]] revolutionized life on the American farm, with manufacturers of [[agricultural machinery]] eagerly taking advantage of occasions like the Illinois State Fair to demonstrate their new products.
The Illinois State Fair was held almost every summer during this more than 150-year-long period. On a few occasions it was suspended. In 1893, for example, the organizers of the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] in Chicago prepared to offer a larger lineup of agricultural products and machinery, so the Illinois State Fair canceled itself for one year.
The Illinois State Fair, like many state fairs, moved during the first 40 years of its life, 1853–92, from place to place. It was celebrated as far north as [[Freeport, Illinois|Freeport]] and as far south as [[Du Quoin, Illinois|Du Quoin]]. In 1894, the State of Illinois began to use a {{convert|156|acre|km2|sing=on}} parcel of land on the northern boundary of Springfield, which became the heart of the permanent Illinois State Fairgrounds. A grandstand and racetrack were built, and the first [[dirt track racing|auto races]] were held at the [[Illinois State Fairgrounds Racetrack]] in 1910. The fairground site was expanded to its current {{convert|366|acre|km2|sing=on}} dimensions in 1924.<ref name="History"/>
During 1895, the Dome Building was constructed on the grounds. The building's huge glass dome, the world's second largest unsupported dome at 222 feet in diameter, had been part of the 1893 Chicago World's Fair. It was purchased for $69,000, taken down in Chicago and reassembled at the state fairgrounds. The building could accommodate 10,000 people and housed horticultural displays and National Guard offices. In 1917, about 1,500 soldiers waiting to go to war were temporarily housed in the Dome Building. On August 17, the building caught fire. Within 30 minutes after the fire was discovered, the huge glass dome came crashing down. At the time of the fire the building was valued at $300,000, but insured for only $20,000, and as a result, the remains of the building were later demolished. Apparently the soldiers were not to blame for the fire nor were any injured by it. [[File:Illinois Dome Building.jpg|thumb|left|The Dome Building]]
There was no state fair during the period 1942-1945 because the fairgrounds were used as a U.S. Army Air Force supply depot. According to one historian, in the fall of 1943 more than 1,000 Chinese military personnel were trained on the grounds.
==Present== Starting with the end of World War II, the growth of productivity in agriculture began to reduce the number of jobs in American farming, both as a percentage of total population and in absolute numbers. State fairs began to transition themselves from agricultural trade shows to entertainment operations.
In Illinois, the State Fair Grandstand, originally built as a place to watch harness racing (and still used for that purpose as of 2015) became a venue for concerts and recitals. The "state fair circuit" became a recognized part of the overall live-music industry for many performers, especially but not exclusively in [[country music]]. Noted concerts held at The Grandstand include [[The Who]], performing as an opening act for [[The Association]] in 1968.
Agricultural show operations, competitions, and judging continued in Springfield, but many State Fairgoers in 2015 were attending the fair to watch parades and spectacles, enjoy the festival rides, listen to music, or drink beer in one of numerous "beer tents."
The Illinois State Fairgrounds now contains more than 100 permanent buildings. In addition, participants set up countless pavilions and trailers during the period the State Fair is in operation. The Illinois State Fair is operated by the [[Illinois Department of Agriculture]], which states in the state's official "Illinois Blue Book" that the purpose of the State Fair is to "showcase Illinois agriculture and offer wholesome family entertainment." <ref>"Illinois Blue Book: 2005-2006", page 215.</ref>
The [[Illinois State Fairgrounds Racetrack|Illinois State Fairgrounds]] are also used as a venue for other competitive and entertainment operations throughout the year, such as [[motorcycle]] and car racing, [[horse show]]s, and [[rodeo]]s.
Reported attendance at the Illinois State Fair was approximately 650,000 in 2003, 671,333 in 2004, 672,615 in 2005, approximately 705,000 in 2006,<ref>Jason George, "A blue ribbon for attendance", Chicago Tribune August 20, 2006, page 15.</ref> 737,052 in 2008,<ref name="Robert"/> 918,435 in 2012,<ref name="Doran">{{cite web |url=http://agrinews-pubs.com/Content/News/Latest-News/Article/Ag-heritage--entertainment-highlight-Illinois-State-Fair-/8/6/10915 |title=Ag heritage, entertainment headline Illinois State Fair |work=AgriNewsIllinois |accessdate=2014-08-08 |format=}}</ref> and 961,142 in 2013.<ref name="Doran"/> After a change in attendance count methodology, reported State Fair attendance dropped sharply. Attendees totaled 411,547 in 2015, 347,855 in 2016, 401,648 in 2017, and 369,144 in 2018.<ref name="SJR"/>
==Cultural references== The Illinois State Fair played a key role in the popularization of the [[corn dog]], starting in 1946.
The fair has long been noted for its annual [[butter sculpture|butter cow]], a life-size animal formed of pure butter applied to an [[armature (sculpture)|armature]] by a sculptor wielding an oversized [[palette knife]]. Among the butter cow's more [[irony|ironic]] admirers was author [[David Foster Wallace]], who covered the 1993 Illinois State Fair for ''[[Harper's]]''; his report on the yellow bovine, and other Fair sights, is reprinted in ''[[A Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again]]'' (1997).
The Illinois State Fair was featured on the [[NBC]]-TV show ''[[The Great American Road Trip]]'' in July 2009.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox play | name = Imaginary Friends | image = ImaginaryFriendsPoster.JPG | image_size = | caption = | writer = [[Nora Ephron]] | chorus = | characters = | mute = | setting = | premiere = September 21, 2002 | place = [[Old Globe Theatre]]
[[San Diego]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = The decades-long rivalry between [[Lillian Hellman]] and [[Mary McCarthy (author)|Mary McCarthy]] | genre = Comedy-drama | web = }} '''''Imaginary Friends''''' is a play by [[Nora Ephron]]. It includes songs with music by [[Marvin Hamlisch]] and lyrics by [[Craig Carnelia]]. This was Ephron's first stage play. ==Plot== Writers [[Lillian Hellman]] and [[Mary McCarthy (author)|Mary McCarthy]] reunite in hell and reflect on their decades-long antagonistic relationship. Dating back to their first meeting at a conference at [[Sarah Lawrence College]] in 1948, it came to a head in 1980 when McCarthy, in a television interview with [[Dick Cavett]], asserted, "every word she writes is a lie, including 'and' and 'the'". Hellman subsequently sued McCarthy for [[slander]]. As the play progresses, the two women recall, among other things, Hellman's 1952 testimony before the [[House Un-American Activities Committee]]; McCarthy's childhood abuse by an uncle; and their romantic involvements: McCarthy with [[Philip Rahv]] and Hellman with [[Dashiell Hammett]]. Throughout it all, McCarthy accuses Hellman of repeatedly presenting fiction as fact, while Hellman insists McCarthy always portrays fact as fiction. ==Productions== Directed by [[Jack O'Brien (director)|Jack O'Brien]], choreographed by [[Jerry Mitchell]], and starring [[Cherry Jones]] as McCarthy, [[Swoosie Kurtz]] as Hellman, and [[Harry Groener]] as all the men in their lives, the play had its world premiere at the [[Old Globe Theatre]] in [[San Diego]], where it ran from September 21 through November 3, 2002. The production transferred to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], opening at the [[Ethel Barrymore Theatre]] on December 12, 2002. It closed on February 16, 2003 after 76 performances and 20 previews. ==Critical reception== In his ''CurtainUp'' review of the San Diego production, Gordon Osmond called it "an uncomfortable cross between [[vaudeville]] and conventional [[musical comedy]]." He observed, "From its outset Act II shows that the production has been hijacked by Mr. Hamlisch and select members of his [[Chorus line|troupe of gypsies]]. The plays breaks out into a rash of stand-alone and largely incongruous musical numbers, which seem concocted for the sole purpose of filling up a record album designed perhaps to defray the production's undoubtedly daunting costs . . . [W]e have a desiccated trial scene which didn't happen in life and shouldn't, in its present form, have happened on stage. The finale consists of an off-stage [[Catfight|cat fight]] between the stuffed doll [[alter ego]]s of Hellman and McCarthy. Having two women of wit, wisdom and letters slug it out physically, albeit offstage, is not just imaginary, it's artistically misguided, pandering to that segment of the audience which doesn't for a moment understand the substance and potential of the play." He concluded, "''Imaginary Friends'' has the feel of a work by a new playwright who was recently quoted as saying that she 'got a taste of the freedom that theater offered . . .' What the playwright failed to recognize is that the theatre has its own rules; e.g., thematic and stylistic consistency." Osmond, Gordon. [http://www.curtainup.com/imaginaryfriends.html "CurtainUp California Review" ] curtainup.com, 2002 In his review of the Broadway production, [[Ben Brantley]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' said it "isn't a show that leaves you gasping at its daring or chuckling over its cleverness. In chronicling a feud between two politically engaged, exceptionally feisty women within a literary world of men, Ms. Ephron makes her points dutifully, clearly and repetitively . . . In trying to appeal to both those who are and those who are not familiar with the play's high-brow heroines, the show winds up sacrificing its dramatic energy to [[Cliff Notes]]-like expositions disguised in [[masque]]rade costumes . . . Mr. Hamlisch's songs, with lyrics by [[Craig Carnelia]], are tuneful, [[jingle]]like numbers that add little in period flavor or character definition. And some of them simply slow things down to no purpose." [http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?res=9805E0DA133AF930A25751C1A9649C8B63 ]''New York Times''{{subscription required}} Reviewing for ''Talkin' Broadway'', Matthew Murray noted Nora Ephron "has a thrillingly theatrical concept that she simply hasn't taken to its furthest extremes. This being her first play, that is perhaps understandable, and ''Imaginary Friends'' is never incompetent or boring. It does manage to be exciting occasionally, but less often than it should be . . . What Ephron gets right is her depiction of Lillian Hellman and Mary McCarthy as [[avatar]]s for the diametrically opposed (maybe) deities of 'fiction' and 'fact.' . . . When ''Imaginary Friends'' tackles that aspect of the story, presenting its scenes with the flair and creativity only theatre can allow, the play is at its best . . . These moments . . . are theatrically astute and emotionally honest . . . Scenes that give us greater insight into the characters are always the most successful and entertaining." He called the songs "the most puzzling component" of the play, commenting, "While the songs don't slow down or detract from the action, they do not particularly enhance it." He concluded, "What is missing, and would probably have made the show more effective, is the literary music created by McCarthy and Hellman. For the most part, their writings - as lyrical and incisive as one is apt to find - are missing from the play, and the contributions of Hamlisch and Carnelia are a poor substitute. Late in the show, when we're reminded of the real legacy these women leave behind in the impressive volume of material each produced, it becomes all too obvious that ''Imaginary Friends'' is weaker for its absence. Given what is present, Nora Ephron could have quite a theatre career ahead of her . . . However, she would be expected to correct her lapses in judgment here in the future; if the addition of the songs was her idea, she should think twice next time and let her characters sing all on their own." [http://www.talkinbroadway.com/world/ImFriends.html "Theatre Review. 'Imaginary Friends'"] ''Talkin' Broadway'', December 12, 2002 ==Awards and nominations== Craig Carnelia was nominated for the [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Lyrics]] but lost to [[Marc Shaiman]] and [[Scott Wittman]] for ''[[Hairspray (musical)|Hairspray]]''.[http://www.ibdb.com/advancesearchaward.asp ''Imaginary Friends''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219011248/http://www.ibdb.com/advancesearchaward.asp |date=December 19, 2013 }} Internet Broadway Database The play was also chosen as one of the ten best plays of the 2002-03 New York theatre season by ''The Best Plays Theatre Yearbook'', where critic Charles Wright wrote “Ephron’s characterization captures the tension of women defying expectations when literature was a men’s club and entry appeared—at times—to depend less on talent than on personal association with a man of established position. . . . At a time when deceptive rhetoric permeated the American ether, Ephron offered a play about prevarication and truth-telling in public discourse—and delivered a message of skepticism about the objectivity of “truth” and the credibility of those with easiest access to the media.”{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/55139647|title=The best plays of 2002-2003|date=2004|publisher=Limelight Editions|others=Jenkins, Jeffrey Eric.|isbn=0879103035|edition= 84th |location=[New York]|oclc=55139647}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IBDB title|13421|Imaginary Friends}} {{Marvin Hamlisch}} {{Nora Ephron}} [[Category:2002 plays]] [[Category:American plays]] [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays set in hell]] [[Category:Plays by Nora Ephron]]

{{italic title}} '''''Irena's Vow''''' is a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] play recounting the story of [[Irena Gut]], a Polish nurse who, at the risk of her life, saved twelve [[Jew]]s during [[World War II]] in [[Nazi Germany|German]]-[[occupied Poland]].<ref name=playbill/>
==Production history== The play opened at Broadway's [[Walter Kerr Theatre]] at 219 West 48th Street (between Broadway and 8th Avenue) on 29 March 2009,<ref name=polestar>"''Przysięga Ireny''" ("Irena's Vow"), ''Gwiazda Polarna'' (Pole Star), vol. 100, no. 7 (March 28, 2009), p. 14.</ref> after having premiered off-Broadway at the Baruch Performing Arts Center in September 2008. The ninety-minute play opened at the Kerr Theatre with the same cast from off-Broadway.<ref name=playbill>Andrew Gans, [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/124530.html "Feldshuh to Return to Broadway in March in Irena's Vow"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081225003521/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/124530.html |date=2008-12-25 }}, playbill.com, 22 December 2008.</ref>
The play was written by [[Dan Gordon (screenwriter)|Dan Gordon]], based on conversations that he had held with Irene Gut-Opdyke (''née'' [[Irena Gut]]). Gordon "captures... peculiarly Polish elements: the heroine's irony and sense of humor in the face of catastrophe." He deftly draws the historic backdrop to Irena's story and creates a suspenseful narrative and "enthralling dialog."<ref name=polestar/>
The title role is played by [[Tovah Feldshuh]]. Appearing in other roles are Sandi Carroll, [[Tracee Chimo]], Steven Hauck, Scott Klaven, [[Peter Reznikoff]], Thomas Ryan, Gene Silvers, John Stanisci and [[Maja Wampuszyc]].
''Irena's Vow'' is directed by Michael Parva. Scenic design is by Kevin Judge; lighting design, David Castaneda; costume design, Astrid Brucker; sound design and music composition, Quentin Chiappetta; and projection design, Alex Koch.<ref name=polestar/><ref name=playbill/>
On June 16, 2009 it was announced that ''Irena's Vow'' will close on June 28. At the time of its closure, it will have played 21 previews and 105 regular performances.<ref>Gans, Andrew.[https://archive.is/20120907082649/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/130282 "Irena's Vow to Close on Broadway June 28,"] playbill.com, June 16, 2009</ref>
==Story== After [[Poland]] was invaded by [[German invasion of Poland|Germany]] and the [[Soviet invasion of Poland|Soviet Union]] in September 1939, [[Irena Gut]], a Polish [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] nurse nineteen year old at the outbreak of [[World War II]], was captured by the Soviet Army. After escaping, she was caught in a German [[łapanka|roundup]] to be used as a [[slave labor]]er.<ref name=polestar/>
Eventually she became the housekeeper to a German army major. After she witnessed the gruesome fate of [[Jew]]s in German-occupied Poland, Gut resolved at the risk of her life to conceal a dozen Jews threatened by the German [[Holocaust]] extermination program. The penalty that the Germans imposed on any Pole found to be harboring or otherwise aiding Jews was death.<ref name=polestar/>
One day Gut's employer discovered that she was concealing Jews in his house. Gut begged him to spare them; he agreed to, and never betrayed them or her. Gut became the German officer's mistress. Before the [[Red Army]] arrived, she fled with the people that she was protecting into the forest. After the war, suspected falsely by some of having collaborated with the Germans, she emigrated to the United States.<ref name=polestar/>
==See also== *[[Irena Gut]] *[[List of individuals and groups assisting Jews during the Holocaust]] *[[Rescue of Jews by Poles during the Holocaust]] *[[2009 in theatre]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *"''Przysięga Ireny''" ("Irena's Vow"), ''[[Gwiazda Polarna]]'' (Pole Star), vol. 100, no. 7 (March 28, 2009), p. 14.
==External links== *[http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=482325 Internet Broadway Database listing] *Andrew Gans, [https://web.archive.org/web/20081225003521/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/124530.html "Feldshuh to Return to Broadway in March in Irena's Vow"], playbill.com, 22 December 2008. *Willborn Hampton, [http://theater2.nytimes.com/2008/09/26/theater/reviews/26iren.html "Hiding Innocents and Keeping Evil at Bay"], New York Times, 26 September 2008.
