{{Infobox military person |name= James Adams Ekin |birth_date= {{birth date|1819|8|31}} |death_date= {{Death date and age|1891|3|27|1819|8|31}} |birth_place= [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]] |death_place= [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]] |placeofburial= [[Cave Hill Cemetery|Cave Hill National Cemetery]], Louisville, Kentucky |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |image=James A. Ekin.jpg |caption= Bvt Brig. Gen. James Adams Ekin
c. 1865 |nickname= |allegiance= [[United States of America]] |serviceyears=1861–1883 |rank=[[File:Union Army colonel rank insignia.png|35px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]]
[[File:Union Army brigadier general rank insignia.svg|35px]] [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] |commands= Chief Quartermaster, [[Cavalry Corps (Union Army)#Cavalry Corps.2C Army of the Potomac|Cavalry Corps]], [[Army of the Potomac]] | |battles=[[American Civil War]] |awards= |laterwork= }} '''James Adams Ekin''' (August 31, 1819–March 27, 1891) was a [[Union Army]] officer in the [[American Civil War]]. He achieved fame as a member of the military commission trying the conspirators involved with the assassination of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Abraham Lincoln]]. ==Early life== Ekin was born August 31, 1819 in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], to James and Susan Burling (Bayard) Ekin. His mother was a daughter of [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] Stephen A. Bayard of the [[Continental Army]]. He served an apprenticeship as a steamboat builder, which eventually led to his first career as a steamboat builder in Pittsburgh. ==Civil War== At the outbreak of the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], Ekin enlisted April 25, 1861 in the 12th Pennsylvania Infantry (a 3-month regiment) as a [[1st Lieutenant#U.S. Army.2C U.S. Marine Corps and U.S. Air Force|lieutenant]] and was assigned regimental quartermaster. Ekin mustered out with the regiment on August 5, 1861 at [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]]. He was subsequently promoted [[Captain (United States)|captain]] and assistant quartermaster August 7, 1861 and served in the Quartermaster's Department. Ekin and was promoted to [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]] February 15, 1864, then promoted again to [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] August 2, 1864. He was [[brevet (military)|brevetted]] in the regular army [[Major (United States)|major]], lieutenant colonel, colonel and [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]], all on March 13, 1865. In addition to his volunteer ranks, Ekin was made a captain in the regular army March 13, 1863, lieutenant colonel and deputy quartermaster general July 29, 1865. ==Lincoln assassination trial== Despite his excellent service in the Army quartermaster department, Ekin is remembered largely for his participation as a member of the [[Military tribunals in the United States|military tribunal]] that heard the case against eight conspirators in the [[Assassination of Abraham Lincoln|assassination]] of President Lincoln. ==Post-war service== Ekin remained in the U.S. Army following the Civil War with the rank of lieutenant colonel and deputy quartermaster general until February 13, 1882 when he was promoted to colonel. He retired from the Army on August 31, 1883. ==Posts== Ekin served at Pittsburgh, as acting assistant commissary of subsistence in 1861; at [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], as assistant quartermaster, 1861–1863; at [[Washington, D.C.]], as quartermaster of the cavalry bureau, 1863–1864; as chief quartermaster of the [[Cavalry Corps (Union Army)#Cavalry Corps.2C Army of the Potomac|Cavalry Corps]], [[Army of the Potomac]], in 1864; as officer in charge of the 1st division, Quartermaster General's Office, Washington, D.C., 1864–1870; as chief quartermaster of the 5th District, Department of Texas, Department of the South, and Department of Louisville, Kentucky until his retirement. ==Family== Ekin married Diana Craighead Walker and together they had five children: James Adams (1844–1847), Nancy Walker (1845–1868), Mary Elizabeth (1847–1934), Susan Bayard (1849), and William Moody (1853–1907). Mary Elizabeth Ekin married [[Augustus E. Willson|Augustus Everett Willson]] July 23, 1877, who served as the 36th [[Governor of Kentucky]], 1907–1911. William M. Ekin followed in his father's career and joined the U.S. Army, rising to the rank of captain in the Quartermaster's Department. Ekin died March 27, 1891 in [[Louisville, Kentucky]] and was buried in [[Cave Hill Cemetery|Cave Hill National Cemetery]].Kentucky Death Records, 1852-1953, Jefferson County, 1891, p. 18. Cause of death is given as "gastric ulcer" for nine years. ==In popular culture== Eakin is portrayed in the film ''[[The Conspirator]]'' (2010) by actor John Deifer. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United States Army|American Civil War}} * [[List of American Civil War brevet generals (Union)]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Eicher, John H. & [[David J. Eicher]]. ''Civil War High Commands'' (Stanford, CA: Stanford University Press), 2001. {{ISBN|0-8047-3641-3}} * Johnson, Rossiter (ed.). ''The Twentieth Century Biographical Dictionary of Notable Americans'' Vol. III (Boston, MA: The Biographical Society), 1904. [See p. 409.] ==External links== {{Commons category|James A. Ekin}} *{{Find a Grave|7154612|accessdate=2011-04-10}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ekin, James A.}} [[Category:1819 births]] [[Category:1891 deaths]] [[Category:Union Army colonels]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:People of Pennsylvania in the American Civil War]] [[Category:People associated with the assassination of Abraham Lincoln]] [[Category:Burials at Cave Hill Cemetery]]

{{Infobox person | name = Janin Ullmann | image = 2012-05-31 Studio Hamburg Nachwuchspreis DSCF0328.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Janin Ulmmann (then Reinhardt) (2012) | birth_name = Janin Reinhardt | birth_date = 14 November 1981 | birth_place = [[Erfurt]], [[Germany]] (Then [[East Germany]]) | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | occupation = [[actress]], tv presenter | yearsactive = 8 | spouse = | domesticpartner = | website = http://www.janin-ullmann.de | academyawards = | afiawards = | arielaward = | baftaawards = | cesarawards = | emmyawards = | filmfareawards = | geminiawards = | goldencalfawards = | goldenglobeawards = | goldenraspberryawards = | goyaawards = | grammyawards = | iftaawards = | laurenceolivierawards = | naacpimageawards = | nationalfilmawards = | sagawards = | tonyawards = | awards = }} [[Image:Die Fantastischen 4.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Janin Reinhardt interviewing the [[Die Fantastischen Vier|Fantastischen Vier]] Thomas D, Smudo and And.Ypsilon]] '''Janin Ullmann''' (born 14 November 1981 as Janin Reinhardt) is a [[Germans|German]] television presenter and [[actress]].
==Biography== Ullmann participated in a [[Casting (performing arts)|casting]] by the German music channel [[Viva (TV station)|VIVA]]. She was chosen from 3000 participants and became the host of ''Interaktiv''. Since then she hosted several television shows as ''Inside'', ''Film ab'', ''Star Search — das magazin'', [[Top of the Pops#Europe|Top of the Pops]], [[Bravo Super Show]], [[Bundesvision Song Contest 2006]] (with [[Stefan Raab]]) and several [[TV total]] specials.
===Acting career=== Ullmann acted in ''[[Was nicht passt, wird passend gemacht (TV series)|Was nicht passt, wird passend gemacht]]'', short film [[Mittsommer (film)|Mittsommer]] (2005) at [[internationale filmschule köln|international filmschool cologne]], comedy show ''PAARE'' on [[Sat.1]] and twice in ''[[Die ProSieben Märchenstunde|ProSieben Märchenstunde]]'' as [[Rapunzel]], with [[Axel Stein]] as [[Hansel and Gretel|Hänsel und Gretel]] and played the lead role in the supernatural horror film [[Die Bienen - Tödliche Bedrohung]].
Ullmann is famous for her performance as ''Lotta'' and ''Alex'' in the [[ProSieben]]-[[Telenovela]] ''[[Lotta in Love]]''.
==Personal life== Ullmann is married to German actor [[Kostja Ullmann]],whom she began dating in 2008<ref>[http://www.gala.de/stars/news/janin-reinhardt---kostja-ullmann--sie-haben--ja--gesagt-20324160.html They said 'Yes'] at Gala.de, 4 October 2007 (accessed 15 September 2017)</ref>

__NOTOC__ {{islamophobia}}
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image: jerry klein.jpg|200 px|right|thumb|Jerry Klein of WMAL 630 AM Radio]] --> On November 26, 2006, radio host Jerry Klein of [[WMAL (AM)|WMAL 630 AM]] (covering [[Washington DC]], Northern [[Virginia]] and [[Maryland]]) had a program that was "focused on public reaction to the removal of six [[imam]]s, or [[Islam]]ic religious leaders, from a [[US Airways]] flight."<ref name="reuters">{{cite news|title=In U.S., fear and distrust of Muslims runs deep | author=Bernd Debusmann | publisher=Reuters|date=February 25, 2007|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSARM55127020070225}} Retrieved on Dec. 16, 2006.</ref> (See ''[[Flying Imams controversy]]''). In an effort to gauge his audience's reaction, he said that force should be applied to ensure that all [[Islam in the United States|Muslims in America]] wear "identifying markers. ...I'm thinking either it should be an [[armband|arm band]], a [[Star and crescent#Use by Muslims|crescent moon]] arm band, or it should be a crescent moon [[tattoo]]. ...If it means that we have to round them up and do a tattoo in a place where everybody knows where to find it, then that's what we'll have to do."<ref name="reuters"/>
The response was overwhelming and "the phone lines jammed instantly". Klein later stated that "The switchboard went from empty to totally jammed within minutes. There were plenty of callers angry with me, but there were plenty who agreed."<ref name="reuters"/> While some callers said he was "off his rocker", others insisted that his statement did not go far enough, calling for [[Population transfer|forced mass exile]]: "Not only do you tattoo them in the middle of their forehead but you ship them out of this country... they are here to kill us." Others called for Muslims to be placed in [[internment camps]]: "You have to set up [[Internment of Japanese Americans|encampments like during World War Two with the Japanese]] and [[German American internment|Germans]]."<ref name="reuters"/>
At the end of the program, Klein revealed that his remarks had been a hoax, saying, "I can't believe any of you are sick enough to have agreed for one second with anything I said. For me to suggest to tattoo marks on people's bodies, have them wear armbands, put a crescent moon on their driver's license on their passport or birth certificate is disgusting. It's beyond disgusting ... because basically what you just did was show me how the German people allowed what happened to the Jews to happen ... We need to separate them, we need to [[Identification in Nazi camps#Numbers|tattoo their arms]], we need to make them wear the [[Yellow badge|yellow Star of David]], we need to put them in [[Nazi concentration camps|concentration camps]], we basically just need to kill them all because they are dangerous."<ref name="reuters"/> A week later, Klein also expressed surprise at how much international media coverage the story got. "You should know that I've received email from around the world, interview requests from the [[BBC]] and [[Channel 4]] in [[England]]".<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|title=At least in America they understand the notion of cultural difference |date=December 11, 2006 |publisher=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/Columnists/Column/0,,1969165,00.html |author=Gary Younge |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212004349/http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2006/dec/11/comment.religion |archivedate=2008-02-12 }} Retrieved Dec. 19, 2006. Reprinted as {{cite news|title=Understanding the notion of cultural difference |author=Gary Younge |date=11 December 2006 |publisher=Mail & Guardian, South Africa |url=http://www.mg.co.za/articlePage.aspx?articleid=292963&area=/insight/insight__comment_and_analysis/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070421135655/http://www.mg.co.za/articlePage.aspx?articleid=292963&area=%2Finsight%2Finsight__comment_and_analysis%2F |archivedate=21 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="milli">{{cite news|title=2006: Another tough year for American Muslims| author=Abdus Sattar Ghazali|publisher=The Milli Gazette|date=23 December 2006| url=http://www.milligazette.com/dailyupdate/2006/200612242_tough_year_American_Muslims.htm}} Retrieved on Dec. 27, 2006</ref>
A [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]] poll the preceding summer had found that 39% of Americans were in favor of requiring Muslims, including those who were citizens, to bear special identification identifying them as such.<ref name="reuters"/><ref name="Guardian"/><ref name="milli"/><ref>{{Cite book |title=Keeping out the other: a critical introduction to immigration enforcement today |editor-first=David |editor-last=Brotherton |editor2-first=Philip |editor2-last=Kretsedemas |page=88 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c7JwBI6ybjIC&pg=PA88 |publisher=Columbia University Press |year=2008 |chapter=Racializing, Criminalizing, and Silencing 9/11 Deportees |first=Irum |last=Sheikh}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Islamophobia]] *[[Internment of Japanese Americans]]

{{Infobox person |name=Joseph O. Carter |birth_name =Joseph Oliver Carter |image=Joseph O. Carter.jpg |image_size= |alt= |caption= |birth_date={{Birth date|1835|12|20}} |birth_place= |death_date={{Death date and age|1909|02|27|1835|12|20}} |death_place= |resting_place= |education= |alma_mater= |known_for=Kingdom of Hawaii Privy Council
Bishop Estate Trustee
Bishop Museum Director
[[C. Brewer & Co.]] President and Manager
Commercial Agent for Japan |spouse=Mary Elizabeth Ladd |parents=Capt. Joseph O. Carter Sr.
Hannah Trufant Lord |children=Charlotte
Mary
Rachel
Joseph Oliver Jr.
Sarah
Henry |occupation =Attorney }} '''Joseph Oliver Carter''' (December 20, 1835 – February 27, 1909), known professionally as Joseph O. Carter, was also known as J. O. Carter and Joe Carter. He was a life-long friend, confidant, and legal advisor to Queen [[Liliʻuokalani]], serving on her Privy Council of State. During the reign of King Kalākaua, Carter was Acting Commercial Agent for Japan, and served two terms as representative in the [[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii]]. He was president of [[C. Brewer & Co.]] in Honolulu. Although he served in the [[Provisional Government of Hawaii]] after the overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii, he was an opponent to annexation by the United States. Carter was trustee of many large estates in Hawaii, and was one of the first directors of the [[Bishop Museum]]. Hawaii diplomat [[Henry A. P. Carter]] was his brother, and [[Governor of Hawaii|Territorial Governor of Hawaii]] [[George R. Carter]] was his nephew. == Early life and family background == He was born December 20, 1835, in a grass house in Honolulu, the first of six children of Massachusetts sea captain Joseph Oliver Carter (1802–1850) and his wife Hannah Trufant Lord (1809–1898).{{cite news|last1=|title=Joseph O. Carter Passed Away This Morning|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1909-02-27/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=February 27, 1909|at=col. 3|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Captain Carter was a trader of Chinese commodities to Hawaii and California, and was the first-generation Carter family immigrant in the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]].{{cite news|last1=|title=Death of Minister Carter|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1891-11-19/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Daily Bulletin|date=November 19, 1891|at=col. 2|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Hannah Trufant Lord of [[Hallowell, Maine]] immigrated to Hawaii in 1832 and married Capt. Carter in 1833, spending the first few years of their married life accompanying him on his voyages.{{cite news|last1=|title="Mother" Carter|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1898-01-31/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Daily Bulletin|date=January 31, 1898|at=col. 2|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} According to [[Governor of Hawaii|Territorial Governor of Hawaii]] [[George R. Carter]], son of Joseph's brother [[Henry A. P. Carter]] (1837–1891), no one in the family was named Joseph Oliver Carter Sr., and the only Jr. was a grandson of the sea captain.{{sfn|Carter|1915|p=4}} Sons Henry and Samuel Morrill Carter (1838–1893) were also born in Honolulu. Son Alfred Wellington Carter (1840–1890) was born aboard the ship Caliope off the coast of Tahiti. Their two youngest children Frederick William Carter (1842–1860), and Catherine Rebecca Carter Lewers (1844–1924) were born in Honolulu.{{sfn|Carter|1915|p=4}} Governor Carter recalled being told by his uncle Joseph that after his birth in Honolulu, he and his mother Hannah accompanied Capt. Carter on a trip to [[Hong Kong]] where the young Joseph was baptized by a British sea captain.{{sfn|Carter|1915|pp=6–7}} On November 28, 1859, he wed Mary Ladd, daughter of William Ladd who formed the sugar cane partnership [[Ladd & Co.]]. Mrs. Carter was a lady-in-waiting to Liliʻuokalani. The couple had six children.{{cite news|last1=|title=Foreign Office Notice|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1892-08-29/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Daily Bulletin|date=August 29, 1892|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|at=col. 1}}{{sfn|Liliʻuokalani|1898|p=290}} == Early career and politics == One of Carter's earliest jobs was as a journalist with the ''Pacific Commercial Advertiser''.{{cite news|last1=|title=Sixty Years a Resident is Joseph O. Carter|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1907-10-19/ed-1/seq-7/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=October 19, 1907|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|at=col. 3}} He was secretary of the local fire department, and then elected as "Delegate to the Fire Department".{{cite news|last1=|title=Honolulu Engine Co. No. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1856-09-25/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=September 25, 1856|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|at=col. 1}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=Election|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1858-07-08/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=July 8, 1858|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|at=col. 4}} Carter was collector of special tax for roads and bridges,{{cite news|last1=|title=Department of Finance|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1859-02-26/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=Polynesian|date=February 26, 1859|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|at=col. 3}} and eventually set up his own office as a tax collector.{{cite news|last1=|title=Tax Payers Awake!|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1860-09-29/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=Polynesian|date=September 29, 1860|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|at=col. 4}} Shortly before the election of King [[Kalākaua]], Carter began to rise in the political arena. He served two terms with the House of Representatives in the [[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii]], for sessions April 30 – July 29, 1872 and January 8 – 20, 1873.{{sfn|Lydecker|1918|pp=123–124}} During the 1874 [[Honolulu Courthouse riot]] provoked by the Legislative Assembly electing Kalākaua over [[Queen Emma of Hawaii|Queen Emma]], former representative Carter sustained injuries when he became a target of mob harassment and violence while helping to rescue legislators. When he refused to leave the scene, the rioters carried him off.{{sfn|Dabagh|1974|pp=81–85, 87}} He was subsequently appointed as Commercial Agent for Japan on September 1880, succeeding J. D. Brewer, and served until the establishment of the Japanese Consulate in 1885 and appointment of [[Jiro Nakamura]].{{sfn|Wakukawa|1938|page=427}} Carter also served as registrar for public accounts.{{sfn|Bonura|Day|2012|pp=327–328}} He began at [[C. Brewer & Co.]] in 1880 as treasurer and secretary,{{cite news|last1=|title=C. Brewer & Co.|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1891-03-17/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Hawaiian Gazette|date=March 17, 1891|at=col. 3|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} and worked his way up to being elected president and manager of the company.{{cite news|last1=|title=New Officers|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1891-07-01/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=July 1, 1891|at=col. 3|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} == Adviser to Liliʻuokalani and annexation == He managed Liliʻuokalani's personal real estate holdings and had been her friend and confidant for years before she ascended to the throne on January 29, 1891. When Liliʻuokalani became regent, Carter was appointed royal adviser on the Privy Council of State.{{cite news|last1=|title=A Well Merited Compliment|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1891-03-02/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=March 2, 1891|at=col. 1|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}{{cite news|last1=|title=Proclamation!|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1891-03-10/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=March 10, 1891|at=col. 1|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} At a June 23, 1892 ceremony at Iolani Palace when Japanese Consul-General Taigo Masaki bestowed Liliuokalani with the Grand Cross of the Imperial Japanese Order of the Crown, Carter was bestowed with Third Class Order of the Sacred Treasurer.{{cite news|last1=|title=The Japanese Consul-General at the Palace Yesterday|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1892-06-24/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=June 24, 1892|at=col. 3|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Liliʻuokalani's proposed [[Proposed 1893 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii|1893 Constitution]] provoked protests, but Carter advised against her cabinet's suggestion of requesting American intervention to maintain civil order. He prepared a proclamation signed by the Queen and her cabinet that promulgation of a new constitution had been abandoned,{{sfn|Alexander|1896|pp=40–42}} but it was not enough to stave off the overthrow and installation of a provisional local government. Carter counseled her to resign under protest, and on January 17 she temporarily ceded her power to the United States.{{sfn|Alexander|1896|p=66}} Following the overthrow, Carter was part of a group sent to Washington D. C. by the provisional government to plead its case for annexation.{{cite news|last1=|title=Revolution in Hawaii|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84025891/1893-02-04/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Washington Bee|date=February 4, 1893|at=col. 3|location= Washington D. C.|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} He was appointed by provisional president [[Sanford B. Dole]] to the Board of Health.{{cite news|last1=|title=An Act to Amend Chapter XI of Session Laws of 1876 relating to Public Health|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1893-03-02/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|at=col. 5|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} President [[Grover Cleveland]] attempted a restoration of the monarchy, with the stipulation that Liliʻuokalani grant amnesty to everyone responsible. Over her demands of beheadings for all involved, Carter obtained her written assent to amnesty.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pp=642–645}} Dole refused to re-instate the Queen, and the [[Republic of Hawaii]] was declared on July 4, 1894.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pp=645, 649}} Carter's standing in the business community suffered from his association with the Queen.{{sfn|Alexander|1896|pp=104–105}} According to Boston author [[Julius A. Palmer Jr.]], Carter's loyalty to her resulted in his being voted out of his position at C. Brewer & Co.{{sfn|Palmer|1894|pp=69, 77–78}} The Queen was put on trial and under house arrest for her alleged part in the [[1895 Wilcox rebellion|1895 Robert Wilcox rebellion]] attempt to restore her to the throne.{{cite web|title=WILCOX, Robert W. – Biographical Information|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=W000459|website=bioguide.congress.gov|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=October 7, 2017}} She was granted a full pardon in October 1896.{{cite news|last1=|title=Liliuokalani Not Under Restraint|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1896-10-24/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=October 24, 1896|at=col. 3|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} When she left Hawaii for the United States in December, seeing her off at [[Honolulu Harbor]] were Carter, on whose arm she leaned as she walked up the gangplank, [[Robert William Wilcox|Robert Wilcox]], and her former Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Samuel Parker (Hawaii)|Samuel Parker]].{{cite news|last1=|title=The Ex-Queen Leaves|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1896-12-04/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Hawaiian Star.|date= October 4, 1896|at=col. 3|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} At an October 1897 gathering of 2,000 anti-annexationists, Carter was the main speaker.{{cite news|last1=|title=Another Meeting of Anti-Annexationists|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1897-10-27/ed-1/seq-7/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Evening Bulletin|date=October 27, 1897|at=col. 4|location= Washington D. C.|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} He traveled to Washington D. C. in January 1898 to lobby against annexation. Newspaper coverage alleged he made the trip at the request of sugar plantation owner [[Claus Spreckels]].{{cite news|last1=|title=Carter to Washington|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016413/1898-01-05/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Evening Bulletin|date=January 5, 1898|at=col. 5|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}{{cite news|last1=|title=Mr. Carter to Come for Royalists|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1898-01-24/ed-1/seq-9/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Evening Star|date=January 24, 1898|at=col. 2|location= Washington D. C.|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} When Hawaii was annexed in 1898, the [[Ceded lands|Crown Lands]] were seized by the United States government. Liliʻuokalani spent the next several years unsuccessfully lobbying the government for return of the Crown Lands, during which she relied on Carter for legal consultation.{{cite news|title=Liliʻuokalani May Sue|newspaper=The Hawaiian Star|date=June 9, 1900|at=col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1900-06-09/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} ==Trustee-estate manager business== Toward the end of his life, Carter was handling all Liliʻuokalani's financial affairs.{{sfn|Bonura|Witmer|2013|pp=122, 126}} Carter was trustee and/or executor of the estates of several members of the Hawaiian nobility, including King [[Lunalilo]].{{cite news|last1=|title=Among the Litigants|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1899-10-04/ed-1/seq-10/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=October 4, 1899|at=col. 3|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Most notably, the trusteeship that occupied much of Carter's final years was the [[Bernice Pauahi Bishop|Bernice P. Bishop]] estate.{{cite web|title=Historical List of Trustees – Bernice P. Bishop Estate {{!}} Kamehameha Schools|url=http://www.ksbe.edu/imua/digital_archived_article/historical-list-of-trustees-bernice-p.-bishop-estate/|website=www.ksbe.edu|publisher=Kamehameha Schools|accessdate=October 7, 2017|language=en}} In addition to being one of the estate's trustees, he was one of the early directors of the [[Bishop Museum]].{{sfn|Bonura|Day|2012|pp=327–328}} Native Hawaiian politician [[John Adams Cummins]], son of High Chiefess Kaumakaokane Papaliʻaiʻaina, made Carter trustee of his estate. {{cite news|last1=|title=Notice (by J. A. CUMMINS)|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1896-10-12/ed-1/seq-8/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=October 12, 1896|at=col.4|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} He was one of the executors of the estate of [[James Campbell (industrialist)|James Campbell]], husband of [[Abigail Kuaihelani Campbell]] who was a descendant of the Kalanikini line of Maui chieftains.{{cite news|last1=|title=James Campbell is Dead|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1900-04-23/ed-1/seq-7/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Honolulu Star|date=April 23, 1900|at=col. 4|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}{{cite news|last1=|title=Bond in Campbell Estate|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1900-06-30/ed-1/seq-7/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.t|date=June 30, 1900|at=col. 3|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} At the time of his death, Campbell was one of the largest landholders in the [[Territory of Hawaii]] and left an estate estimated at $3,000,000.{{cite web|title=The Story of James Campbell - James Campbell Company LLC|url=https://www.jamescampbell.com/about/the-story-of-james-campbell/|website=James Campbell Company LLC|accessdate=October 7, 2017}}{{cite magazine |last=Youn |first=Jacy L. |title=James Campbell Estate |journal=Hawaii Business |date=20 November 2001 |url=http://www.hawaiibusiness.com/james-campbell-estate/ |accessdate=October 7, 2017}} He was designated as trustee and/or estate manager of numerous non-nobility trusts, including that of his brother Henry A. P. Carter,{{cite news|last1=|title=Executor's Notice to Creditors (estate of H. A. P. Carter)|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1892-01-12/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=January 12, 1892|at=col. 2|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} and as a trustee of Central Union Church.{{cite news|last1=|title=Dedicated:The Congregation of the Central Union Church Move Into the New Building|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1892-12-05/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=December 5, 1892|at=col. 1|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Samuel C. Allen, Kauai businessman, developer and financial backer of [[Port Allen, Hawaii]], left an estate in excess of $2,000,000 in 1903, naming Carter as one of his executors.{{cite news|last1=|title=Inventory Estate of Late Sam C. Allen|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-07-18/ed-1/seq-8/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.t|date=July 18, 1903|at=col. 2|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} ==Death== Mary Carter died December 15, 1908 after an extended illness. Her obituary noted her close friendship with Liliʻuokalani.{{cite news|last1=|title=Sudden Death of Mrs. J. O. Carter|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1908-12-16/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 7, 2017|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|date=December 16, 1908|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|at=col. 4}} Joseph O. Carter died of [[pulmonary edema]] on February 27, 1909. His sister Catherine Rebecca Carter Lewers was his only surviving sibling. The Carters were survived by their children Joseph Jr., Henry, Charlotte, Mary, Rachel and Sara. == Notes == === Citations === {{Reflist|33em}} === Bibliography === *{{cite book|first=William DeWitt|last=Alexander|author-link=William DeWitt Alexander|title=History of Later Years of the Hawaiian Monarchy and the Revolution of 1893|date=1896|publisher=Honolulu, Hawaiian Gazette Company|location=Honolulu, HI|url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001261379|via=[[HathiTrust]]|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last1=Bonura|first1=Sandra|last2=Day|first2=Deborah|title=An American Girl in the Hawaiian Islands: Letters of Carrie Prudence Winter, 1890–1893|date=2012|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|isbn=978-0-8248-3722-8|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/book/17628|via=[[Project MUSE]]|subscription=yes|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal|last1=Bonura|first1=Sandra|last2=Witmer|first2=Sally|title=Lydia K. Aholo — Her Story Recovering the Lost Voice|journal=Hawaiian Journal of History|publisher=Hawaiian Historical Society|date=2013|volume=47|hdl=10524/36266|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last1=Carter|first1=George Robert|author-link=George R. [[Image:LampSizeCm.jpg|thumb|Lamp of Brotherhood in [[Vancouver]]]] A '''Lamp of Brotherhood''' or '''''Fraternitatis Lumen''''' is one of 84<ref name=Banbury/> decorative [[oil lamp]]s cast from the [[bronze]] doors of the destroyed [[Monte Cassino Abbey]] in Italy. The original Lamp was first lit in the Abbey in 1950.<ref name=CNP>{{cite news |title=12th Brotherhood Lamp is Lighted |newspaper=Catholic Northwest Progress |location=Seattle, Washington |date=27 July 1962 |page=5 |url=http://cnp.stparchive.com/Archive/CNP/CNP07271962p05.php}}</ref><ref name=Schrijvers>{{cite book |title=The Margraten Boys: How a European Village Kept America's Liberators Alive |first=Peter |last=Schrijvers |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |date=15 Mar 2012 |isbn=9780230346635 |pages=99–100}}</ref>
The "Lamp of Brotherhood" presently in [[Vancouver|Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada, is 31 cm long, 10.5 cm wide, and 14.5 cm high. Text on the upper surface reads: "Fraternitatis Lumen".
== History == After [[World War II]], Italian war widows began a movement to reconcile nations that had participated in the war, on both sides.<ref name=Schrijvers/> In 1950, they organized a visit of families of those who had died in the war to several sites, including the Monte Cassino Abbey, where the original Lamp of Brotherhood was placed.
This initiative grew and by the late 1950s it had become the World Organization of the Lamp of Brotherhood (''Opera Mondiale della Lampada della Fraternità''), a subsidiary of the [[Pontificia Commissione di Assistenza]] led by Bishop [[Ferdinando Baldelli]].<ref name=Ellison>{{cite book |title=Ralph Ellison |first=Arnold |last=Rampersad |publisher=Knopf Doubleday |date=2007 |isbn=9780307267320 |quote=Fanny went with some trepidation to the headquarters of the Pontificia Opera di Assistenza,...At stake was a job with a subsidiary group, the Lampada della Fraternità, or the Lamp of Brotherhood, which had been founded in 1950 to serve the families of soldiers killed in Italy and abroad.}}</ref><ref name=Schrijvers/><ref name=CNP/> A ceremony was held in the partially re-built Monte Cassino in 1956, in which Lamps were given to representatives of many nations. Each country that received a Lamp was intended to create a national ''Lampada'' organization, which was to have custody of the Lamp.
===Vancouver Lamp=== The Vancouver Lamp arrived in Vancouver through the participation of Air Vice Marshal Ken Guthrie<ref>[http://www.sturgeon.ab.ca/guthrie/guthrie.htm Air Vice Marshal Kenneth M. Guthrie]</ref> in the original Lamp service in 1956. Guthrie said that he and his wife were the only representatives from North America at this Lamp-giving ceremony and it was placed in their custody.
No "Lampada" organization was started in North America, and so the Lamp remained in the custody of Ken and Kay Guthrie. The Lamp was a focal point at a ceremony in [[Sainte-Agathe-des-Monts|Sainte-Agathe, Quebec]] in 1959. A Mrs. Stockdale, National President of the [[Silver Cross Mother|Mothers of the Silver Cross Association]] laid the Lamp at the base of the Cenotaph. The Guthries brought the Lamp to Vancouver in 1964. There, the Lamp has been a focal point of the annual [[Battle of Britain]] ceremony at the Air Force Garden of Remembrance in [[Stanley Park]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legionbcyukon.ca/content/battle-britain-ceremony-sept-15 |title=Battle of Britain Ceremony Sept 15 |date=5 Sep 2013 |publisher=Royal Canadian Legion BC/Yukon Command |accessdate=26 Jan 2015}}</ref>
==Known Lamps == ;Italy – Monte Cassino Abbey: The original Lamp
;Canada – Vancouver: The Lamp is used in the annual [[Battle of Britain Day|Battle of Britain]] ceremony.
;Netherlands – Christus Koning Church (Vredeskerk) at Venray: The church was designed as a peace memorial, where a Lamp of Brotherhood would burn as a symbol of peace.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kerkgebouwen-in-limburg.nl/view.jsp?content=865 |title=Christus Koning (Vredeskerk) |website=Kerkgebouwen in Limburg |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref> The church closed in 2000, and has been converted into an office building.
;Netherlands – [[Margraten]]: In 1957 a Lamp was lighted at the [[Netherlands American Cemetery|American military cemetery in Margraten]].<ref name=Schrijvers/>
;New Zealand – [[National War Memorial (New Zealand)|National War Memorial]]: The Lamp is mounted in the Hall of Memories of the War Memorial.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mch.govt.nz/nz-identity-heritage/national-war-memorial/hall-memories |title=Hall of Memories |date=15 Jan 2015 |accessdate=25 Jan 2015 |publisher=New Zealand Ministry for Culture and Heritage}}</ref>
;England – [[St Mary's Church, Banbury]]: A Lamp of Brotherhood from Monte Cassino was installed in 1964. It is cited as one of 84.<ref name=Banbury>{{cite web |url=http://odg.org.uk/history/banbury/banbury_st_mary.html |title=St. Mary, Banbury, Oxon |date=2009 |publisher=Oxford Diocesan Guild of Church Bell Ringers |accessdate=25 Jan 2015}}</ref>

The '''Lessons Learnt and Reconciliation Commission''' (LLRC, {{lang-si|උගත් පාඩම් හා ප්‍රතිසන්ධාන කොමිෂන් සභාව}} ''Ugath Padam Ha Prathisandhana Komishan Sabhava''), {{lang-ta|கற்றுக்கொண்ட பாடங்கள் மற்றும் நல்லிணக்க ஆணைக்குழு}}) was a [[Truth and reconciliation commission|commission of inquiry]] appointed by [[President of Sri Lanka|Sri Lankan President]] [[Mahinda Rajapaksa]] in May 2010 after the 26-year-long civil war in Sri Lanka.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sri Lanka Profile|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11999611|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> The commission was mandated to investigate the facts and circumstances which led to the failure of the ceasefire agreement made operational on 27 February 2002, the lessons that should be learnt from those events and the institutional, administrative and legislative measures which need to be taken in order to prevent any recurrence of such concerns in the future, and to promote further national unity and reconciliation among all communities.{{Citation needed|reason=where did this come from? the actual document?|date=January 2014}} After an 18-month inquiry, the commission submitted its report to the President on 15 November 2011. The report was made public on 16 December 2011, after being tabled in the [[Parliament of Sri Lanka|parliament]].<ref>{{cite news|title=President Releases LLRC Report To Parliament, The UN And Public|url=http://www.thesundayleader.lk/2011/12/18/president-releases-llrc-report-to-parliament-the-un-and-public/|newspaper=The Sunday Leader|date=18 December 2011|accessdate=29 December 2011}}</ref>
The commission concluded that the [[Sri Lanka Armed Forces|Sri Lankan military]] didn't deliberately target civilians but the rebel [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]] (LTTE) repeatedly violated international [[humanitarian law]].<ref name=CBS161211>{{cite news|title=Sri Lankan commission: Civilians weren't targeted |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-501712_162-57344039/sri-lanka-war-commission-rules-out-willful-attacks/ |newspaper=[[Associated Press]]/[[CBS News]] |date=16 December 2011 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> According to the commission the military gave the "highest priority" to protecting civilians whereas the Tamil Tigers had had "no respect for human life".<ref name=BBC161211>{{cite news|title=Sri Lanka MPs receive controversial civil war report|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16214783|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> The commission admitted that civilians had been killed by the Sri Lankan military, albeit accidentally, contradicting the government's line that there were zero civilian casualties.<ref name=SMH191211>{{cite news|last=Doherty|first=Ben|title=Sri Lanka war report lays blame on both sides|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/sri-lanka-war-report-lays-blame-on-both-sides-20111218-1p0sg.html|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=19 December 2011}}</ref> The commission did, however, receive some eyewitness evidence alleging abuse by the military which warranted further investigation and, if necessary, the prosecution of perpetrators.<ref name=AJ201111>{{cite news|title=Sri Lanka war probe calls for new inquiry|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2011/11/201111201146094228.html|newspaper=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=20 November 2011}}</ref> The commission acknowledged that hospitals had been shelled, resulting "considerable civilian casualties", but it did not say who was responsible for the shelling.<ref name=BBC161211/> The commission blamed Sinhalese and Tamil politicians for causing the civil war: the Sinhalese politicians failed to offer a solution acceptable to the Tamil people and the Tamil politicians fanned [[Sri Lankan Tamil militant groups|militant separatism]].<ref name=SMH191211/>
The commission has been heavily criticised by international human rights groups, the [[Report of the Secretary-General's Panel of Experts on Accountability in Sri Lanka|UN Panel of Experts]] and others due its limited mandate, alleged lack of independence and its failure to meet minimum international standards or offer protection to witnesses.<ref name=BBC161211/><ref name=C4161211>{{cite news|title=Sri Lankan civilians 'not targeted', says report|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/sri-lankan-civilians-werent-targeted-says-report|newspaper=Channel 4 News|date=16 December 2011}}</ref> These critics believed that the Sri Lankan government was using the commission as a tool to prevent an independent international investigation of [[Alleged war crimes during the Sri Lankan Civil War|alleged abuses]].<ref name=FL031211>{{cite journal|last=RADHAKRISHNAN|first=R. K.|title=The report of the Lessons Learnt and Reconciliation Commission of Sri Lanka may lack credibility in international fora|journal=[[Frontline (magazine)|Frontline]]|date=3–6 December 2011|volume=28|issue=25|url=http://www.hindu.com/fline/fl2825/stories/20111216282505000.htm|publisher=[[The Hindu Group]]}}</ref> As a consequence of this [[Amnesty International]], [[Human Rights Watch]] and the [[International Crisis Group]] refused to appear before the commission.<ref name=BBC141010>{{cite news|title=Human rights groups snub Sri Lanka war crime inquiry|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-11542053|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=14 October 2010}}</ref>
==Background== Tensions between the [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]] and [[Sri Lankan Tamil people|Tamil]] communities in Sri Lanka turned into a full-scale war between the Sri Lankan government and LTTE in 1983. In 2002, government and the LTTE signed a Norwegian-mediated ceasefire. Both LTTE and the government resumed fighting in 2006, and the government officially backed out of the ceasefire in 2008. After a violent last few months, in May 2009, the government killed LTTE leader [[Velupillai Prabhakaran]] and declared an end to the civil war.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sri Lanka Profile|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12004081|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> Following the end of the war, international pressure mounted on the government to inquire into the final stages of the civil war, in which it was alleged thousands of civilians, possibly as many as 40,000, were killed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Report of the Secretary-General's Panel of Experts on Accountability In Sri Lanka|url=https://www.un.org/News/dh/infocus/Sri_Lanka/POE_Report_Full.pdf|publisher=[[United Nations]]|date=31 March 2011}}</ref> Over the course of the entire war, between 60,000 and 100,000 deaths.<ref name="ABC200509">{{cite news | title = Up to 100,000 killed in Sri Lanka's civil war: UN | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/20/2576543.htm | newspaper = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC Australia]] | date = 20 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sri Lanka|url=. http://topics.nytimes.com/top/news/international/countriesandterritories/srilanka/index.html?scp=1-spot&sq=sri%20lanka&st=cse|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> There were calls to look into the root causes of the civil war and meaningful reconciliation. The [[Sri Lankan government]] rejected calls for an independent ''international'' inquiry but instead on 15 May 2010, nearly a year after the end of the civil war, President Rajapaksa appointed the Lessons Learnt and Reconciliation Commission to look back at the conflict Sri Lanka suffered for 26 years.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sri Lanka: President appoints Lessons Learnt and Reconciliation Commission|url=http://reliefweb.int/node/354905|publisher=ReliefWeb|date=17 May 2010}}</ref> Its secretariat was established at the [[Lakshman Kadirgamar Institute of International Relations and Strategic Studies]] in [[Colombo]]. Hearings of the commission, which commenced on 11 August 2010, were public and open to media, unless the witness requested otherwise. The LLRC issued some interim recommendations on 13 September 2010. Time limit to produce the final report was extended twice, until 15 November 2011.<ref>{{cite news|last=Reddy|first=B. Muralidhar|title=Reconciliation panel's term extended|url=http://www.hindu.com/2010/11/09/stories/2010110962020700.htm|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=9 November 2010}}</ref> Hearings were held in Colombo and in former conflict affected areas such as [[Batticaloa]], [[Jaffna]], [[Kilinochchi]], [[Mannar, Sri Lanka|Mannar]] and [[Vavuniya]]. Field visits were conducted to the former war zone and detention centres where surrendered [[Tamil Tiger]] combatants were held. After analysing over 1,000 oral and 5,000 written submissions it had received, the commission presented its 388-page final report to the President on 15 November 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=LLRC report tabled in Parliament: "Security Forces had not deliberately targeted civilians in the NFZs" - LLRC|url=http://www.priu.gov.lk/news_update/Current_Affairs/ca201112/20111216llrc_report_tabled_parliament.htm|date=16 December 2011|accessdate=29 December 2011}}</ref> It was made public on 16 December 2011.
==Mandate== The mandate of the LLRC was as follows:<ref name="1658/19">{{cite journal|title=Proclamations & c., by the President |journal=The Gazette of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka Extraordinary |date=16 June 2010 |volume=1658/19 |url=http://www.documents.gov.lk/Extgzt/2010/PDF/Jun/1658_19/1658_19%20(E).pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004025059/http://www.documents.gov.lk/Extgzt/2010/PDF/Jun/1658_19/1658_19%20%28E%29.pdf |archivedate= 4 October 2011 |df= }}</ref>
"To inquire and report on the following matters that may have taken place during the period between 21 February 2002 and 19 May 2009, namely: * The facts and circumstances which led to the failure of the ceasefire agreement operationalized on 21 February 2002 and the sequence of events that followed thereafter up to the 19th of May, 2009. * Whether any person, group or institution directly or indirectly bear responsibility in this regard; * The lessons we would learn from those events and their attendant concern, in order to ensure that there will be no recurrence; * The methodology whereby restitution to any person affected by those events or their dependants or their heirs, can be affected; * The institutional administrative and legislative measured which need to be taken in order or prevent any recurrence of such concerns in the future, and to promote further national unity and the reconciliation among all communities, and to make any such other recommendations with reference to any of the matters that have been inquired into under the terms of the Warrant."
==Members== The LLRC's eight members were:<ref name="1658/19"/> *1. [[C. R. De Silva]], [[President's Counsel (Sri Lanka)|PC]] (chair) - [[Attorney General of Sri Lanka|Attorney General]] (2007–09); [[Solicitor General of Sri Lanka|Solicitor General]] (1999–2007); Deputy Solicitor General (1992–97) *2. [[A. Rohan Perera]], [[President's Counsel (Sri Lanka)|PC]] - former legal advisor to the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Sri Lanka)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] and current member of the [[International Law Commission]] *3. Karunaratne Hangawatte - Professor of Criminal Justice at the Department of Criminal Justice, [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] and former consultant to the United Nations<ref>[http://www.dailynews.lk/2010/05/18/news23.asp Pen sketch of commissioners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522035044/http://www.dailynews.lk/2010/05/18/news23.asp |date=2010-05-22 }}</ref> *4. Palihakkara]] - former Secretary, [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Sri Lanka)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] and former Permanent Representative to the United Nations *6.
